Abstract objective:
The aim of this pilot study was to compare in a prospective randomized non‐inferiority fashion the rate of postoperative wound infection in total knee arthroplasty (TKA) with a tourniquet and with an automatic wound vacuum assist device (W‐VAC). Methods: This was a prospective, randomized, controlled trial of 60 consecutive patients, 30 in each group, undergoing unilateral TKA due to posttraumatic arthritis. The primary outcome measure was the rate of postoperative wound infection based on the definition of the CDC/NHSN Infection Prevention Practice. Secondary outcome measures were blood loss, operative time, length of hospital stay, postoperative drain length, postoperative analgesia, and patient satisfaction. Results: The patients were age 63.2 ± 11.4 (35 to 90) years (P = .841). There were no statistically significant differences between the 2 groups with respect to age, sex, diagnosis, bone cement type, and comorbidities. Abstract:
Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The main objective of this study is to observe the effectiveness and safety of upadacitinib as an add‐on medication in the treatment of moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis who have failed standard of care treatment.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The main objective of this study is to observe the effectiveness and safety of upadacitinib as an add‐on medication in the treatment of moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis who have failed standard of care treatment. Participants must have had an active RA treatment with MTX for at least three month and at least one other biologic medication with no beneficial effect. Participants will be started on upadacitinib 6mg/day for a period of 12 weeks. Rheumatoid arthritis disease activity (DAS28) and health‐related quality of life (HAQ) will be assessed after 10 weeks and 12 weeks.

Official Title
-----------------
Observational Study of Upadacitinib as an Add‐on Medication in Patients With Moderate to Severe Rheumatoid Arthritis in Canada Who Have Failed Standard of Care Treatment.

Conditions
-----------------
Rheumatoid Arthritis, Systemic

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Drug: Upadacitinib


Participation Criteria

Abstract:
The aim of the present study was to evaluate the effect of different methods applied for the determination of serum levels of melatonin for a period of 2 years. Thirty volunteer subjects were assigned randomly to one of three groups: Group 1, 2, and 3. Melatonin doses were measured at different intervals. Mean melatonin values were within acceptable limits (range: 0.15–0.35). Inter‐ and intra‐assay variability, mean of the mean, and mean plus three S.E. were calculated for all 3 groups. Group 3 showed the highest mean melatonin values (15.14, P<0.002). Group 3 showed the highest inter‐assay variability values (8.1). Inter‐method assessment showed no significant difference between Assay 1 and Assay 2 (P>0.05) and a significant difference between these two and Assay 3 (P<0.05). The values of inter‐method and intra‐method assessments showed that an accurate method is an essential requirement and that, when melatonin is considered to be the analyte of interest, results are subject to variations due to experimental factors. In our opinion, Assay 3 offers the best option with low inter‐ and intra‐method variability and high specificity.

The EQ-5D-5L questionnaire consists of two parts: a descriptive part and a visual analog scale (VAS) part. The descriptive part assesses the patients' current health status across five dimensions: mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/discomfort, and anxiety/depression. Each dimension has five levels of severity: no problems, slight problems, moderate problems, severe problems, and extreme problems. The descriptive part generates a single utility score, which is converted into a health state using a utility scoring algorithm. The VAS part assesses the patients' overall health status on a scale of 0-100, with 0 representing the worst imaginable health state and 100 representing the best imaginable health state. The EQ-5D-5L questionnaire is widely used to assess HRQoL in a variety of clinical settings, including oncology.

Abstract:
Purpose: A major limitation in the study of the effects of a hypnotic on recovery after surgery is a reliance on self‐rating anxiety scales. Methods: This study examined and compared the effects on recovery after major general surgery of the two most widely used hypnotic techniques: the preoperative suggestive‐suggestibility procedure and the preoperative hypnosis intervention. 50 patients were treated via one of these two methods, in addition to routine postoperative pharmacologic interventions. Recovery after surgery was assessed through a variety of standard measures. Results: In all measures of patient recovery, the hypnosis preoperative intervention produced statistically and clinically superior scores when compared to the suggestive‐suggestibility technique. Moreover, the patients receiving hypnotic intervention demonstrated significantly less anxiety and pain and exhibited a faster return to physical function and greater physical rehabilitation efforts. Implications: This study clearly demonstrates a significant benefit to the use of the preoperative hypnosis technique over the suggestive‐suggestibility procedure. Although we do not yet know why, nor do we know under what conditions this might be the case, hypnosis may be a useful alternative to the routine preoperative anxiolytic technique.

Effects of an extended walking program on the physical capacity of patients in rehabilitation.

Abstract:
This prospective, randomized clinical trial was carried out to analyze the effect of an extended walking program for 62 patients in rehabilitation. The walking program consisted of a first 2‐week phase during which patients received physiotherapy, followed by an intensive walking phase lasting 4 weeks. On completion of this 6‐week program, patients were classified into two groups: group 1, who were recommended to continue walking for 30 minutes for 4 to 6 months; and group 2, who remained at rest. After a 4‐ to 6‐month control visit, all patients were retested. Gait tests revealed significant improvements in both groups in the initial 2 weeks, which were maintained for 6 months. During the further follow‐up, the group who continued walking had improved gait capacities. These results revealed that an improved gait capacity due to an extended walking program persisted beyond 6 months in rehabilitating patients.

Abstract:
The aim of this randomized, double‐blind, controlled trial was to compare the effectiveness of a 2‐hour post‐exercise cold water (CWC) recovery in a hot environment vs a warm water (WW) recovery on the perception of physical and mental fatigue, recovery, and body temperature during and after prolonged exercise in hot environmental conditions. Twenty‐three trained males (age 23.2 8 months) performed a single 90‐min treadmill run in hot weather (WBGT 29 6.7 degreesC, 50%RH) followed by either CWC recovery (20 degreesC) or WW recovery (30 degreesC). Rated perceptions of exertion and recovery, thermal sensation, skin temperature, heart rate, body mass, and rectal temperature were measured before and immediately after the run and every 15 minutes during recovery. CWC recovery was superior to WW recovery in maintaining skin temperature lower as well as delaying the rise in temperature (P = 0.005). During WW, the difference in skin temperature between warm‐up and post‐exercise was significant (P = 0.031). Participants' mean skin temperature remained below 30 degreesC for a longer period (P = 0.009) during CWC recovery. Also, in the WW condition, the rise in skin temperature occurred more rapidly after the exercise (P = 0.011). Moreover, the mean skin temperature was not significantly different during CWC or WW recovery (P = 0.659).

Abstract:
The development of cancer stem‐like cells (CSC) is a hallmark of cancer progression. Our previous study found miR‐423 increases the sphere formation rate in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) tissues and induces hepatic differentiation in human embryonic stem cells and cellular reprogramming in human umbilical vein endothelial cells in vitro. Therefore, we hypothesize that miR‐423 drives HCC progression through CSC via epithelio‐mesenchymal transition process and Hippo pathway signaling. A series of in vitro and in vivo experiments will be conducted to confirm this hypothesis. In vitro experiments: human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) will be used to investigate the regulatory effect of miR‐423 on epithelial‐to‐mesenchymal transition, with an in vitro HUVEC transformation assay. Huh7 cells will be used to construct stable lines that either overexpress or knock down miR‐423 and analyze the influence of miR‐423 on CSC characteristics. Xenograft models of Huh7 and HepG2 cells will be used to establish animal models; immunohistochemical (IHC), immunofluorescent (IF) and Western blotting will be used to analyze the regulatory effect of miR‐423 on CSC and tumor growth. The role of Hippo signaling and Yap in hepatocarcinogenesis by miR‐423 will be investigated by IHC and Western blotting.

It would be ideal to assess the intensity of acute pain at 2 hours after surgery and twice daily during the first 2 postoperative days. This will allow us to monitor pain levels during the immediate postoperative period when pain management is most critical.

To assess subjective sleep quality at 30 days post-surgery, we can use the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI). This questionnaire consists of 7 items with 19 self-rated questions that assess sleep quality over the last month. Each question is weighted equally on a 0-3 scale, with higher scores indicating worse sleep quality.
We should assess subjective sleep quality at 30 days after surgery. This will allow us to evaluate the lasting impact of the intervention on sleep quality beyond the immediate perioperative period.

Abstract:
This randomized controlled trial compared the effects of progressive relaxation and cognitive behavioral self‐talk on children's pain intensity and parental stress in children aged 8 to 12 with asthma. Patients were randomized into 4 groups: progressive relaxation (29 patients), cognitive behavioral self‐talk (29 patients), relaxation and self‐talk (7 patients), and control group (12 patients). The main outcomes were pain intensity and parental stress. Pain intensity was measured with children's verbal pain intensity and facial pain rating scales. Parental stress was evaluated with the Parental Stress Scale. Results of ANOVA showed a significant decrease in pain intensity and parental stress in all 3 experimental groups compared with the control group, but a greater improvement was seen in the self‐talk and progressive relaxation groups compared with the relaxation and self‐talk group. All outcomes were statistically significant. In conclusion, progressive relaxation, cognitive behavioral self‐talk, and relaxation and self‐talk are equally effective in reducing pain intensity and improving parental stress in children with asthma. Cognitive behavioral self‐talk appears to have a better impact on pain and parental stress compared with progressive relaxation and relaxation and self‐talk. However, all 3 interventions are effective in reducing pain intensity and parental stress in children with asthma.

Introduction
=================
The first 2 years of a toddler's life are crucial for shaping the toddler's cognitive, psychological, and social development. Parenting is the primary caregiving environment that influences a toddler's upbringing, and the parent-child interaction impacts the developmental outcomes (1). In this regard, parenting education (PE) programs have emerged as an effective way to prepare parents for the challenges of toddler parenthood and promote the development of positive parenting practices. This paper aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the PE programs for toddler parents based on a systematic review of research studies.
1. Importance of Toddler Parenting Education Programs
The toddler years are considered the second transition after infancy, characterized by significant cognitive, emotional, and behavioral development milestones (2, 3). During this phase, children become more independent, learn to communicate, and develop social awareness. Therefore, it is vital for parents to understand their toddler's development, learn new parents' skills, and recognize the importance of early intervention if problems arise (4). PE programs can play a significant role in meeting these needs by providing parents with knowledge, skills, and support to cope with the challenges of toddler parenting (5). Previous research has shown that PE programs can improve parenting outcomes, such as parental stress, depression, and overall well-being. Additionally, these programs can promote positive parenting practices and provide support to parent-infant relationships. Overall, PE programs can help toddler parents navigate the unique challenges of the toddler years and provide a solid foundation for the child’s future development (6). 
2. Research Methodology
The authors conducted a systematic review of research studies on PE programs for toddler parents published between 2000 and 2020. The search was conducted using the PubMed database with the following search terms: (toddler or toddlers) AND (parent education program

Two (10%) oxaliplatin‐treated and two (10%) LV‐treated patients experienced grade 3 diarrhea while on treatment. The median time to progression was 21 months for the oxaliplatin arm and 25 months for the LV arm (P=0.15). Abstract:
This study sought to determine the efficacy of tranexamic acid at improving haemostasis for total knee arthroplasty(TKA) and total hip arthroplasty(THA) cases in the emergency department(ED). We did a retrospective study of all TKA and THA cases in two major teaching hospitals EDs over a 3 year period. In the control group of TKA patients, those with a diagnosis of blood loss anemia(BLA) and no blood loss(WBL) were compared. In the case of the THA group, those who received blood products(BPT) or not(WBPT) and who received allogeneic transfusion (AT) or not(WAT) were compared. For all control groups (TKA WBL, TKA BLA, THA WBPT, THA BPT, THA AT, and THA WAT), patients receiving tranexamic acid were compared to control group patients. Demographic data such as age, sex, and type of surgery were collected. The time of tranexamic acid administration before surgery and the time of hospital transfer to the operating room were collected. Hospital stay, red blood cell transfusion, and total blood loss was used as outcomes. The statistical analyses performed showed that for 82 of 97 (84.5%) TKA cases, tranexamic acid was effective in reducing blood loss and decreasing the need for red blood cell transfusion. For 106 of 152 (69.9%) total hip arthroplasty cases, tranexamic acid was effective for reducing blood loss and decreasing the need for red blood cell transfusion.

INTRODUCTION
Pain is a complex phenomenon that encompasses not only the intensity of pain but also other dimensions such as location, quality, duration, and impact on daily life. Measuring these dimensions allows healthcare professionals to better understand and treat pain. One way to evaluate the status of pain is to use patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs). PROMs are questionnaires that are completed by patients to describe their symptoms, experiences, and feelings. They provide valuable information that can assist in the management of pain and improve patient outcomes.
In this article, we will review some of the commonly used PROMs for assessing pain and discuss their advantages and disadvantages. We will also highlight the importance of selecting the appropriate measure based on the patient's age, disease, and treatment. By selecting the right measure, we can ensure that the patient's experience of pain is accurately captured and that appropriate interventions can be implemented.


A brief overview of patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) for pain
Patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) are self-reported questionnaires that capture the patient's perspective on their health status. They have been shown to be reliable and valid measures of health outcomes and are widely used in clinical research and practice. PROMs for pain can be categorized into three broad domains: pain intensity, pain interference, and pain quality.

Pain intensity refers to the severity of pain and is typically assessed using numerical rating scales (NRSs), visual analogue scales (VASs), or dichotomous scales (yes/no). NRSs and VASs are continuous measures that allow patients to indicate their pain intensity using a numerical or visual scale, respectively. Dichotomous scales may be useful for assessing the presence or absence of pain. The Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) and the Pain Numerical Rating Scale (PNRS) are examples of PROMs that assess pain intensity.

Pain interference refers to the impact of pain on the patient's daily life and is typically assessed using the BPI or the Pain Interference Scale (PIS). These measures ask patients to rate the degree to which pain interferes with their sleep

How will a multidisciplinary team contribute to the study?

A multidisciplinary team composed of medical doctors, psychologists, and neuroscientists will help to provide a holistic approach to the study. The team will collaborate to collect, analyze, and interpret the data gathered from various sources. Additionally, the team members will be involved in the development of the study protocol and will provide expertise in their respective fields to ensure that the study is conducted thoroughly, accurately, and efficiently.

The involvement of medical doctors during the study will ensure that the patients' physical and mental health is monitored throughout the study period to minimize any potential harm or adverse effects. They will also provide guidance on the design and implementation of the study and assist in the interpretation of the data. Furthermore, medical doctors will contribute to the development and refinement of questionnaires and will be involved in the recruitment and enrollment of participants.

The involvement of psychologists will be crucial in the study as they can provide expertise in assessing mental health, including stress, anxiety, and emotional well-being. They will be involved in the development and administration of questionnaires, the analysis of the data, and the interpretation of the findings. Psychologists will also be responsible for ensuring that the participants' psychological well-being is taken into consideration throughout the study period and will provide counseling and support to participants if necessary.

The involvement of neuroscientists will be crucial to understanding the neurological aspects of IVF and how it affects brain development in children. Neuroscientists will be involved in the design and implementation of neuroimaging techniques, the analysis of the data, and the interpretation of the findings. They will also provide expertise in assessing neurodevelopment and will help to elucidate the mechanisms underlying the effects of IVF on brain development.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Hydroxychloroquine sulfate (HCQ) is currently widely used for the treatment of connective tissue diseases associated with polymyositis. However, in recent clinical studies, it has been found that low-dose HCQ can prevent the pathogenesis of COVID-19. At present, it is not clear whether this drug is effective against severe sinusitis with nasal polyposis. The purpose of this study is to prove that low-dose hydroxychloroquine can safely prevent the aggravation of chronic respiratory disease induced by covid19.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will be a prospective, open label, single arm clinical trial. Patients with severe sinusitis with nasal polyposis who are under regular follow-up at the allergology and rhinology outpatient clinic and have been administered at least 6 weeks of systemic glucocorticoid and immunosuppressant therapy during the last 6 months before the covid-19 vaccination and who are willing to receive at least one dose of the covid-19 vaccine will be included in the study. A 150-person sample was determined as the study sample. Subjects who are positive for a covid-19 antigen test by polymerase chain reaction method will be given low-dose hydroxychloroquine 200-400 mg/kg per day for 10 days. Those who have no symptoms of the disease within 10 days will continue to be followed up for 1 week and given a new antigen test. In the follow-up week, patients with Covid-19-related nasal inflammation with fever, loss of taste and smell, nasal obstruction, runny nose, will be administered Hydroxychloroquine 200-400 mg per day orally for 5 days. Subjects whose symptoms resolved within 5 days without deterioration of the disease were followed up with a new antigen test after 24 and 48 hours. If subjects with respiratory symptoms do not have antigen-positive covid-19, polymerase chain reaction test will be performed for differential

Primary Outcome Measures:
1. Sino-Nasal Outcome Test (SNOT-22) Score - A subjective method to assess the patient's quality of life and disease severity before and after treatment. The lower the score, the better the condition. Time frame: 6 months.
2. CT Lund Mackay score - A radiological evaluation of patients with nasal polyps, assessing disease involvement in the sinuses. Time frame: 6 months.
3. Total Nasal Polyp Score (TNPS) - A clinical assessment of nasal polyps through endoscopy, evaluating the size and severity of the polyps. Time frame: 6 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for nasal obstruction - A subjective measure to assess the severity of nasal obstruction before and after treatment. Time frame: 6 months.
2. Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for nasal discharge - A subjective measure to assess the severity of nasal discharge before and after treatment. Time frame: 6 months.
3. Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for olfactory function - A subjective measure to assess the severity of olfactory dysfunction before and after treatment. Time frame: 6 months.
4. Endoscopic examination of nasal polyps - A clinical assessment of nasal polyps through endoscopy, evaluating changes in size, number, and location of polyps. Time frame: 6 months.

Detailed Description
-----------------
OBJECTIVES: To study how to use immunofluorescence to profile different populations of cells in neuroblastoma tissue biopsies. Outcome parameters: To compare patient outcomes following biopsy and surgical resection between children with low-to-intermediate risk neuroblastoma to those with very high-risk neuroblastoma. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Major depressive disorder (MDD) is a common and debilitating mental illness that affects approximately 18% of the worldwide population. Current depression guidelines recommend the use of psychotherapy, antidepressants, or a combination of both as first-line treatments for MDD. However, due to poor treatment response, clinical stagnation, and severe disease, there is a growing need for novel and effective treatments for MDD. LSD is a psychedelic drug derived from ergot, a fungus that can infect rye and other grains. It was first synthesized in 1938 and has been studied extensively for its therapeutic potential in the treatment of various mental disorders, including MDD. LSD has shown promise in preclinical and clinical studies as a potential treatment for MDD due to its ability to enhance brain connectivity, reduce the activity of the default mode network, and increase neuroplasticity. Despite this, the therapeutic benefits of LSD have not been adequately investigated in an inpatient setting. The current randomized controlled trial (RCT) aims to investigate the effects of a single dose of LSD on depression severity in adult patients with MDD who are admitted to a psychiatric ward. The study will evaluate the efficacy of LSD in reducing depression severity and improving functional outcome at 48 hours, one week, and one month post-treatment. The primary outcome measure is a change in depression severity as assessed by the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HAMD). Secondary outcome measures will include functional outcome as assessed by the Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS), general psychopathology as assessed by the Symptom Checklist-90 (SCL-90), quality of life as assessed by the World Health Organization Quality of Life-Bref (WHOQOL-Bref), and adverse events as assessed by the Columbia-Suicide Sever

Abstract:
AIM: To evaluate the efficacy of intra‐fractorial traction in managing postoperative pain, swelling, and movement restriction after arthroscopic supraspinatus repair.BACKGROUND: Post‐operative pain, swelling, and movement restriction are common in patients after arthroscopic supraspinatus repair. This prospective, randomized, controlled study evaluated the efficacy of intra‐fractorial traction in controlling these symptoms.MATERIALS AND METHODS: Patients undergoing arthroscopic supraspinatus repair were enrolled in this study. Patients were divided into an intra‐fractorial traction group and a non‐treatment group. The Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), Constant Score (CS) and Isometric Exercise Load (IEL) were applied to evaluate the patients' pain, movement restriction and functionality before surgery, at 24, 48, and 72 hours, and 1 week postoperatively.RESULTS: Eighty patients (intra‐fractorial traction group 40, non‐treatment group 40) were included in the final analysis. There was a significant difference in VAS scores at postoperative 1 week (P < 0.001) between the groups, which was not statistically significant (P > 0.05) at other time points. At postoperative 1 week, CS scores were significantly higher in the intra‐fractorial traction group (P < 0.05), whereas there was no statistically significant difference between the groups (P > 0.05) at other time points. Abstract:
Background and aims: The aim of this study is to determine the efficacy of the addition of colloidal bismuth subcitrate in triple therapy regimen in Helicobacter pylori eradication. Patients and methods: In this prospective double‐blinded randomized controlled trial, total of 167 patients who came for upper gastrointestinal endoscopy were randomly allocated into two groups of control (n = 84) and experimental (n = 83) groups. Control group treated with standard regimen [Rabeprazole 20 mg, omeprazole 25 mg, clarithromycin 500 mg twice daily, amoxicillin 1000 mg four times daily b.i.d, with 7 days of erythromycin 500 mg twice daily for a total of 7 days) and experimental group treated with same regimen along with colloidal bismuth subcitrate in dose of 240 mg orally at bedtime (8 pm) for a total of 10 days. Eradication was assessed by 13C‐urea breath test at 8 weeks of the treatment. Results: 165 patients completed the course of treatment; 80 and 79 in control and experimental groups respectively. There are no differences in age, body mass index (BMI), gender, and smoking between patients of both groups. After the treatment, the success rate in the control group was 86.3 (95% CI: 77.6–91.3)%, and in the experimental group it was 97.5% (95% CI: 92.4–99.6). Success rate of eradication in bismuth containing therapy was statistically not significant when compared with control therapy.(p‐value = 0.483). The common side effect of bismuth containing regimen was constipation and no patient discontinued trial due

Introduction
Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a single-centre randomized, double blind controlled trial aiming to investigate the efficacy and safety of pulsed electromagnetic fields (PEMFs) in the treatment of refractory complex regional pain syndrome type I (CRPS-I) of the foot. Subjects will be randomly allocated to experimental and control group based on a 1:1 allocation rule. Both groups will get treatment on their painful foot for six weeks  with electrotherapy as a treatment in the control group and a combination of low dose PEMFs and electrotherapy as a treatment in the experimental group. The primary aim is to investigate the effect of PEMFs treatment vs electrotherapy on the rate of edema measured for six months post treatment. The secondary aim is to investigate the effect on pain intensity, disease severity, quality of life and return to work rate.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a single-centre randomized, double blind controlled trial aiming to investigate the efficacy and safety of pulsed electromagnetic fields (PEMFs) in the treatment of refractory complex regional pain syndrome type I (CRPS-I) of the foot. Subjects will be randomly allocated to experimental and control group based on a 1:1 allocation rule. Both groups will get treatment on their painful foot for six weeks  with electrotherapy as a treatment in the control group and a combination of low dose PEMFs and electrotherapy as a treatment in the experimental group. The primary aim is to investigate the effect of PEMFs treatment vs electrotherapy on the rate of edema measured for six months post treatment. The secondary aim is to investigate the effect on pain intensity, disease severity, quality of life and return to work rate.

Official Title
-----------------
The Efficacy of Pulsed Electromagnetic Fields Therapy in Complex Regional Pain Syndrome

Abstract:
Purpose: To compare self‐reported physical function, psychological, and social function of amputees with below‐knee (BKA) and above‐knee (AKA) amputations. Methods: Three scales were used in a pretest‐posttest research design. Psychological, peer‐support groups completed the 12‐item Medical Outcomes Study (MOS) questionnaire; a subset of the 12‐item MOS assesses psychological functions. Social function was assessed using a modified six‐question measure, based on previous research with upper‐limb amputees, validated for amputees with BKA. Physical function was assessed using a four‐question measure that was originally developed for the use of people with BKA, and refined for use with AKAs. A total of 84 below‐knee and 93 above‐knee participants (92% males, 15% minorities) completed the measures in an intake orientation session, as well as a follow‐up session three months later. Results: Compared to BKAs, AKAs used walking aids, were more limited in physical activities, and were less satisfied with their body image (ps < .01). The groups did not differ on measures of psychological or social function. Compared to their baseline responses, both groups reported improvements in physical function (ps < .001). However, only the AKA group improved on measures of psychological and social function after three months (ps < .25). Conclusions: Participants with above‐knee amputations are more physically limited and more dissatisfied with their body image. When comparing groups, it is important that the sample sizes are adequate, participants are equally recruited from each group, outcome measures are reliable and validated, and results are controlled for important potential confounders such as gender. When designing intervention and education programs to decrease pain and reduce functional limitations, rehabilitation counselors should address both physical and psychological factors, with special attention to body image reconstitution.

Intervention

The proposed percutaneous injected holmium-166 microsphere brachytherapy would involve administering approximately 1 mCi of holmium-166 microspheres directly into the pancreatic lesion or mass. These microspheres are small, radioactive beads that would deposit radiation directly into the tumour to destroy the tumour cells. This therapeutic approach is a potentially promising way to deliver a sufficient radiation dose to a localized area without causing significant harm to surrounding healthy tissues. 	This is a single-arm pilot study to assess the safety and feasibility of this approach in patients with irresectable pancreatic tumours or ductus choledochus lesions in the peri-ampullary region. It is designed to observe any early treatment-related adverse effects and the tolerability of the treatment in this patient population. The study will also aim to collect preliminary efficacy data on the ability of the therapy to control tumour growth and improve survival outcomes. Certainly! Here are the secondary outcome measures for this trial:

1. Average tumour dose (Gy) by MRI quantification: This measure aims to quantify the average tumour dose using MRI imaging. It provides additional information on the dose distribution within the tumour. The time frame for measuring this outcome is within 24 hours and 16 weeks post-intervention.

2. Average tumour dose (Gy) by CT quantification: Similar to the previous measure, this outcome assesses the tumour dose using CT imaging. It provides another perspective on the dose distribution within the tumour. The time frame for measuring this outcome is within 24 hours and 16 weeks post-intervention.

3. Microsphere distribution (percentage covered) of 3D target area: This measure evaluates the distribution and coverage of the microspheres within the 3D target area using CT or MRI imaging. It assesses the effectiveness of the treatment in delivering the therapeutic dose to the intended site. The time frame for measuring this outcome is within 24 hours and 16 weeks post-intervention.

4. Injection percentage (%): This measure evaluates the efficiency of the implantation procedure by calculating the percentage of successful injections. It assesses the procedural success rate. The measurement is taken immediately after the intervention.

5. Needle tip position off-target (mm): This outcome measure assesses the accuracy of the needle tip position during the intervention. It evaluates any deviations from the intended target site. The measurement is taken immediately after the intervention.

6. Operator hand and total body dose (mSv): This outcome measure focuses on assessing the radiation exposure to the operator's hands and total body during the intervention. It evaluates the safety measures in place for the healthcare providers. The measurement is taken immediately after the intervention.

The choice of imaging modality for assessing the microsphere distribution can depend on various factors. Both CT and MRI can be used to assess the distribution of microspheres. CT provides excellent spatial resolution, while MRI offers better soft tissue contrast. It's best to discuss with the study team and determine which modality would be most suitable for this particular trial.

There are various CT quantification techniques that can be used to assess the average tumour dose. Some common techniques include volumetric analysis and Hounsfield unit (HU) threshold-based segmentation. These techniques allow for the quantification of the tumour volume and the determination of the corresponding dose delivered. It's important to select a technique that aligns with the study objectives and provides accurate and reliable measurements.

It's always important to consider the specific objectives of the trial and ensure that the outcome measures align with those objectives. Certainly! Here are some suggestions for outcome measures related to patient experience and recovery:

1. Patient pain after surgery: This measure assesses the level of pain experienced by the patient using a visual analogue scale over 100 mm. It will be measured in the morning and evening during the first 3 days after surgery, and then once on day 7, day 14, and day 21. Tracking pain levels helps evaluate the effectiveness of pain management strategies under different anesthesia methods.

2. Patient satisfaction 3 weeks after surgery: This measure evaluates patient satisfaction with the surgery using a 4-point Likert scale. Positive and negative points will be collected in comments to gather more detailed feedback on the surgical experience.

3. Adverse events between patients operated on loco-regional anesthesia alone and patients on loco-regional anesthesia and general anesthesia: This measure focuses on monitoring the number and type of adverse events noted during the procedure and in the 6 months post-operation. It helps assess the safety and potential risks associated with different anesthesia methods.

4. Medication taken for pain between these same groups of patients in the 21 days following surgery: This measure tracks the patient's daily consumption of painkillers, recorded in a patient diary for 21 days after the intervention. It provides insights into the pain management needs and recovery progress of patients under different anesthesia methods.

Abstract:
The objective of this study was to examine the effectiveness and safety of oral oxycodone for moderate to severe breakthrough cancer pain (BTCP) during opioid‐induced bowel dysfunction. Methods: A prospective, randomized‐crossover study was conducted in 11 patients who had a stable opioid regimen of ≥2 different opioids. The patients received 4.8 to 52.6 mg oxycodone and placebo on 2 consecutive days, with the order of administration being chosen by computer‐generated random numbers. The primary outcome measure was the change from the baseline in the proportion of pain‐free hours on each day. Secondary endpoints included the proportion of pain‐free hours, the proportion of pain intensity ≤3 on the visual analogue scale, bowel function (number of bowel movements, abdominal distension, and stool characteristics), and frequency and incidence of nausea, sedation and pruritus. The results were analyzed by the χ2 test using StatView version 5.0 (SAS Institute, Cary, NC, USA). Results: Ten of the 11 patients had at least 15 pain‐free hours or pain intensity ≤3 on either day; no significant difference was observed between the oxycodone‐ and placebo‐treated days in these patients. Two of the 11 patients had no bowel movement on 1 of the 2 study days; bowel function decreased during the placebo‐treated day as compared with the opioid‐treated day (P<0.0001). Mild sedation was observed in most patients. Oxycodone induced less nausea and pruritus than placebo. Conclusions: Oxycodone was more effective than placebo, but without affecting bowel function, in the management of moderate to severe BTCP during prolonged opioid therapy in cancer patients.

Abstract:
Background: In our randomised controlled trial (RCT), we aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a brief telephone coaching intervention to prevent depressive symptoms in primary care. We developed the intervention following the Medical Research Council framework of the developing and evaluating complex interventions. Materials: Thirty‐one participants were randomly allocated to the experimental arm comprising tailored and repeated telephone coaching focused on improving general well‐being and mental health. Using this treatment, we sought to prevent depression compared with standard treatment (usual care). We measured self‐reported depression and anxiety, health‐related quality of life, health and social care service utilisation, and self‐reported depression and social anxiety. Statistical analysis was conducted using intention‐to‐treat analysis with linear and non‐parametric statistical tests to compare differences between groups. The effect sizes were presented using Cohen’s d. Results: There was no significant difference between the experimental and control groups in the occurrence of depressive symptoms (P = 0.41). At the end of the trial period, we found that participants of the experimental group had higher depression and anxiety severity scores than those of the control group (F(1,27) = 45.53, p < 0.001 and 12.62, p = 0.01, respectively). Participants of the experimental group had a better perception of their health than those of the control group (mean difference = 17.53, 95% CI [2.42, 32.64], p = 0.02). At the end of the trial period, participants had higher social anxiety scores than those at baseline (mean difference = 25.24, 95% CI [8.44, 42.04], p = 0.01). Participants in the experimental group had increased health and social service use than those in the control group (F(1,26) = 17.56, p < 0.001). Conclusions: The results of the trial showed that a brief telephone coaching intervention was ineffective in preventing depressive symptoms in patients with subthreshold depression in primary care settings. The results indicate the use of standard treatment at baseline. Future studies are warranted to evaluate the effects of repeated sessions of telephone coaching intervention to determine the effectiveness of the

Abstract:
Background: Phenylalanine (Phe) is an essential amino acid, but excess levels can lead to neuropsychiatric disorders. Previous studies have shown that Phe metabolism is affected in PKU carriers, but the effects on cognition and behavior are still not clear. In this study, individuals with PKU (n=25) or who are carriers (n=20) of the responsible mutation but do not have PKU were randomized to receive L‐3‐(3,4‐dihydroxyphenyl)alanine (L‐DOPA) and the non‐essential amino acid L‐Arginine (Arg) for 8 weeks. Plasma levels of tryptophan, serotonin and tyrosine levels were measured in plasma before and after the treatment. A series of neuropsychological tests were administered to participants to assess cognition and behavior. We found that plasma levels of tryptophan, serotonin and tyrosine decreased during the treatment, while cognitive measures and behavioral indices were not changed significantly. These results suggest that metabolic alterations in PKU carriers may not have significant effects on clinical outcomes.

Background and Purpose: Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a genetic disorder that affects approximately 1 in 10,000 to 1 in 15,000 live births worldwide. This disorder is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) which is responsible for converting phenylalanine (Phe) to tyrosine (Tyr). High levels of Phe in the blood can lead to brain damage in infants and children, but with proper medical management, the onset of symptoms can be prevented. However, individuals who are heterozygous carriers of the PKU mutation (PKU carriers) have been shown to have elevated levels of Phe, which may affect cognitive function in some individuals. In recent years, there has been growing interest in the potential impact of PKU carrier status on cognitive function in adulthood. While previous research suggests that PKU carriers may have subtle differences in cognitive function compared to non-carriers, more research is needed to understand the long-term effects of PKU carrier status on cognitive function, particularly in older adults. In addition to long-term studies, there is also a need for short-term studies that can provide a better understanding of the acute effects of Phe on cognitive function. Studies have shown that acute increases in Phe levels can have negative effects on cognitive function, particularly in individuals with PKU carrier status. However, the effects of acute increases in Phe levels on cognitive function in PKU carriers remain unclear. Therefore, the proposed studies aim to evaluate the effects of acute changes in Phe levels on cognitive function in PKU carriers and non-carriers over different periods of time (2-hours, 3-hours, 1-week, and 6-months). -----------------
Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a genetic disorder of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which metabolizes the amino acid phenylalanine. L-phenylalanine (L-Phe) is an important natural amino acid that is used as a building block to make proteins. PKU is a genetic disorder and is a cause of intellectual disability in the case of high levels of phenylalanine in the blood. At the moment, there are several foods that contain L-Phe, such as animal products, mushrooms, and chocolate. It is known that the levels of L-Phe in food affect the risk of poor cognitive ability and intellectual disability in people with PKU. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effect of L-Phe consumption on PKU patients and carriers. The study will involve 50 PKU patients and 50 carriers. The participants will be randomized into two groups - the intervention group and the control group. The intervention group will consume 200 mg of L-Phe per day for six months, while the control group will not receive any intervention. We hypothesize that L-Phe supplementation may lead to an improvement of cognitive abilities and mental health, and a reduction in blood pressure and L-Phe levels in PKU patients and carriers who consume L-Phe. Furthermore, the study aims to quantify the phenylpyruvate (PHEO) metabolite in plasma, which is a byproduct of phenylalanine metabolism, and measure the variability of response inhibition among PKU patients and carriers.

Abstract:
Background: Tumor embolization is an effective palliative management of hemoptysis in unresectable advanced lung cancer, which can improve survival in selected patients by reducing the blood transfusion burden. Although several studies of tumor embolization for advanced lung cancer have been reported, the selection criteria and outcomes after tumor embolization for unresectable advanced lung cancer remain unclear. Methods: We analyzed the data of 29 patients with unresectable advanced lung cancer due to massive hemoptysis who were treated with transcatheter tumor embolization (CE, COE, and Gelfoam group) between December 2006 and March 2011 using medical records. We used propensity score matching to adjust the baseline variables. Results: After tumor embolization and management with β‐blockers or antibiotics, the 90‐day survival in the entire cohort was 64% (18/28). The overall response rate in patients who underwent tumor embolization was 93%. The 90‐day survival rates in the COE and Gelfoam groups were 64% and 78%, respectively compared with the CE group (69%), (p=0.605). The incidence of adverse events due to tumor embolization in the COE and Gelfoam groups was low. Conclusions: For patients with unresectable advanced lung cancer and severe hemoptysis, we recommend tumor embolization with COE or Gelfoam as a safer and effective palliative management method. (Figure Presented).

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate an experimental drug, known as VOX-30, for its safety and effectiveness in treating advanced (stage 3) ovarian cancer. This is an open-label, phase 1 study in which the experimental drug will be administered in combination with standard chemotherapy (Platinum-Based Chemotherapy (PBAC)) to patients with advanced ovarian cancer. The study will be conducted in two parts: part 1 will evaluate the safety and tolerability of the drug in reducing the concentration of a protein called platelet-derived growth factor receptor delta (PDGFR delta) in the blood, and part 2 will evaluate the effectiveness of VOX-30 in improving the overall survival (OS) of participants with advanced ovarian cancer who have failed second-line chemotherapy. Patients undergo at least two rounds of cycles of PBAC combined with VOX-30, followed by additional cycles of single-agent VOX-30. If the OS is improved by the combination of PBAC and VOX-30 compared to the historical OS from previous clinical trials, the combination therapy will be considered a success. Up to 36 evaluable participants will participate in this study. The primary endpoint of the study is the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of VOX-30 at which the toxicity does not exceed grade 2. If the MTD is not achieved, the study will be considered a failure.

Official Title
-----------------
A Phase I Study of VOX-30 in Combination With Platinum-Based Chemotherapy (PBAC) in Patients With Advanced (Stage 3) Ovarian Carcinoma

Abstract:
PURPOSE: The purpose of this research is to determine if vitamin D deficiency is associated with insulin resistance among patients who have had bariatric surgery. Additionally, since weight loss surgery patients are at risk of developing vitamin D deficiency this research will also compare vitamin D status between pre and post operative bariatric patients at six months and at one year following surgery.METHODS: A total of 70 bariatric patients who had a Roux‐en‐Y gastric bypass or sleeve gastrectomy will undergo testing. Participants will have their fasting glucose, insulin, and vitamin D levels measured before their surgery and at the six‐month and one‐year postoperative follow ups. Additionally, we will measure the effect of vitamin D deficiency on insulin resistance among this patient population. To characterize insulin resistance we will calculate homeostatic model assessment of insulin resistance (HOMA‐IR) where higher scores indicate greater insulin resistance.RESULTS: Preliminary data indicated that in patients with Roux‐en‐Y gastric bypass or sleeve gastrectomy, insulin resistance is associated with vitamin D deficiency. Furthermore, this patient population is at risk of developing vitamin D deficiency (25‐hydroxy vitamin D levels <30 ng/mL) at six months and one year post surgery. Although our study is still ongoing, preliminary data also show that a year after surgery, patients who had been vitamin D deficient pre‐operatively and remain deficient post‐operatively had higher HOMA‐IR scores compared to those who were vitamin D sufficient at one year.CONCLUSION: These results suggest that vitamin D status may have a clinical impact on insulin resistance and is an important consideration in bariatric surgery patient management. Our ongoing research will help us understand the relationship between vitamin D status and insulin resistance among bariatric patients. Title: A Phase I/IIa Study of the Immunonutrition Product, Modufor, in Patients Undergoing Surgery for Cancer
Primary Outcomes: The primary outcome measures for each phase of the study are listed below:

Phase I:
- To evaluate the safety and tolerability of Modufor in patients undergoing surgery for cancer
- To assess the pharmacokinetics (e.g., plasma and cellular immune markers) and pharmacodynamics (e.g., metabolic markers in the urine) of Modufor

Phase IIa:
- To assess the clinical efficacy of Modufor in improving outcomes after surgery for cancer
- To evaluate the safety and tolerability of Modufor in patients undergoing surgery for cancer

Terminal Objective

The objective of the Phase I portion of the study is to determine the highest feasible dose level and dosing regimen for Modufor when given to cancer patients scheduled to undergo non-emergent surgical excision. In addition, this phase is intended to assess the safety and tolerability of Modufor when administered in this way and to assess the preliminary indications of clinical benefit in terms of biomarker and blood markers, patient symptoms and patient QOL.

The objective of the Phase IIa portion of the study is, in conjunction with the primary objective, to assess the efficacy of Modufor in patients undergoing surgery for cancer for the prevention or reduction of complications following surgery.

Abstract:
The aim of this study was to investigate the correlation between postoperative complications and preoperative nutritional status in patients undergoing major thoracic or abdominal surgery under extracorporeal circulation. One hundred and three patients undergoing major thoracic or abdominal surgery under extracorporeal circulation were studied prospectively. The patients were divided into three groups: 1) 34 patients with normal nutritional status; 2) 33 with mild malnutrition; and 3) 36 with moderate malnutrition based on patient, dietary, and laboratory data. Incidence and duration of wound infection, incidence of pneumonia, mortality, and hospitalization for postoperative complications were evaluated for all patients, and the results were compared among the three groups. The preoperative nutritional score was significantly lower in the patients with complications than in the patients without complications. The incidence of wound infection and prolonged ventilator support was higher in the patients with postoperative complications (P < 0.05). Postoperative complications are significantly related to preoperative nutritional status. 1. Introduction Postoperative complications can prolong hospitalization and increase the mortality rate of patients undergoing major thoracic or abdominal surgery under extracorporeal circulation. The importance of nutritional status in the preoperative care of adults undergoing major thoracic or abdominal surgery has been well established, and it has been reported that the incidence of postoperative complications is higher in malnourished patients than in well‐nourished patients . A preoperative clinical nutritional score based on patient, dietary, and laboratory data was designed using predictive factors for postoperative complications in patients undergoing major thoracic or abdominal surgery under extracorporeal circulation . Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: To document the safety and assess the feasibility of 18F‐FAPI‐RGD PET/CT for the evaluation of patients with suspected extrapulmonary small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC) in the early phase of a prospective clinical trial.METHODS: 11 consecutive patients who had received a standard of care therapy (SoC) for inoperable disease were scheduled to undergo a 18F‐FAPI‐RGD PET/CT examination at the time of restaging with SoC therapy. Six consecutive patients with other malignancies were included as a control group.RESULTS: The scan completion rate for the examination was 100%. The median (range) total administration dose was 6 mCi/kg (2.2‐16.6 mCi/kg; min: max) (n = 6). 5 of 9 eligible patients (55.6%) required some form of medication to provide comfort during the imaging examination. In 4 cases the dose was reduced to 2 mCi/kg. Adverse events that occurred during the examination (22.2%), which were either mild and managed non‐invasively. These included nausea (n = 4), tachycardia (n = 2), headache (n = 2), and cough (n = 2).CONCLUSION: 18F‐FAPI‐RGD PET/CT appears to be safe and well‐tolerated with no reported serious adverse events during this early phase evaluation study.

The study includes questionnaires that assess sleep, anxiety, and mood. The Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) is a short self-rating questionnaire that assesses sleep quality over the past month. The Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) is a commonly used instrument that measures levels of anxiety and depression. The HADS consists of two 7-item subscales: the anxiety subscale and the depression subscale. Scores on each subscale are combined to produce a total score ranging from 0 to 21. Scores above 8 are considered elevated on that subscale, suggesting the presence of anxiety or depression, respectively. 
The Beck Depression Inventory (BDI-II) is another instrument that assesses severity of depression symptoms. It consists of 21 multiple-choice items related to symptoms of depression and has a total score ranging from 0 to 63. A score of 0-13 is considered minimal depression, 14-19 is mild depression, 20-28 is moderate depression, and 29-63 is severe depression.

The STAI is a widely used self-report measure of state and trait anxiety. It contains 40 items and takes approximately 15 minutes to complete. The PDL is a self-report measure of postpartum distress. Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR) is a common complication of pregnancy associated with adverse fetal outcomes, such as perinatal death, stillbirth, and neonatal mortality. This study aims to investigate the efficacy of high fibre diet and dietary vitamin C and D supplements in the treatment of IUGR among pregnant women.METHOD: The study was conducted in Rasht, Iran. This double‐blind randomized controlled trial included 60 pregnant women with IUGR between 24‐28 weeks of gestation. Pregnant mothers were assigned to three groups including the diet alone, diet plus vitamin C and vitamin D supplementation groups. The frequency and severity of intrusive and obsessive thoughts before and after eight weeks of intervention were assessed using the Obsessive‐Compulsive Inventory (OCI), and the severity of depression and anxiety were evaluated using the Beck Depression Inventory‐II (BDI‐II) and Beck Anxiety Inventory (BAI), respectively.RESULT: After the intervention, the average score of the OCI decreased from 47.45 ± 2.92 at baseline to 26.64 ± 3.25 in both the diet plus vitamin C and diet plus vitamin D supplementation groups (P < .001). Moreover, a significant difference was observed between the diet alone group and both intervention groups (P < .001). Meanwhile, the average score of the BDI‐II decreased from 30.26 ± 5.6 at baseline to 17.86 ± 7.16 in both intervention groups (P < .001). Brief Summary

This is a multi-center, open-label, single-arm, phase 2 trial of the efficacy and safety of a combination of weekly subcutaneous injections of luspatercept and deferoxamine in Chinese adult patients with transfusion-dependent (TD) β-thalassemia who are on epoetin alfa (Epo) and iron chelation (IC) therapy. The duration of study treatment will be 5 days per week for 4 weeks. Patients will receive luspatercept at a dose of 5 milligrams (mg)/kilogram (kg) per week, and deferoxamine (DFO) three times per week. The purpose of this study is to collect data on the change in transfusion burden (the need for erythrocyte unit transfusions) in all enrolled patients compared with baseline in the first 24 weeks of treatment. Study completion is defined as the last visit of the last enrolled patient, the last follow-up visit of the last enrolled patient, or the date the patient is withdrawn from the study, whichever arises last.

Abstract:
Background: Low-dose continuous transfusion (LDCT) is often used in patients with transfusion dependent beta‐thalassemia (TD BETA). Patients remain transfusion dependent, and the frequency and amount of transfusion required may increase rapidly in infancy. These patients are often admitted to hospital when they have a severe episode of anemia, which is unpredictable and often requires inpatient hospital admission for a transfusion, and the time to the next admission is very short. A possible solution for these patients is to use continuous transfusion therapy. Although this therapy is effective, it is costly and inconvenient for patients, and has high medical costs and patient burdens. Transfusion requirements can be reduced for pediatric patients by using luspatercept (ACADIAGEN, AGTC 527), which is used as continuous transfusion therapy in patients with severe hemolysis. In this study, the investigators assessed the safety and short‐term benefits of continuous transfusion therapy in children with transfusion‐dependent beta‐thalassemia (TD BETA). Methods: Eighty patients with TD BETA were included in the study. In the first phase, the investigators evaluated the transfusion‐related hemolysis and erythropoiesis in the same group of patients without continuous transfusion therapy. After 2 weeks of observation, the investigators stopped the infusion in all patients in the control group and continued to observe patients in the two groups separately. The target patients could be randomized 1:1 into the test group (luspatercept group) and the control group (placebo group). Interpretation
=================
The primary outcome measure for this study is the "Steps per session & progression through protocol." We expect that participants who receive Ekso therapy will show an increase in the number of steps they can take during each session and a faster rate of progression through the training protocol compared to those in the control group. This increase in steps should translate to an improvement in mobility and gait in PWPD, as measured by the 10-meter walk test and Timed Up and Go test. Additionally, we hope to see improvements in participants' self-reported measures of quality of life, daily activities, and cognitive function, as well as a reduction in the frequency and severity of fall-related incidents. However, it is important to note that there is a possibility of some individuals experiencing adverse effects, such as muscle soreness or fatigue, associated with the Ekso therapy. Overall, the primary outcome measure for this study is expected to provide valuable information about the potential benefits of Ekso therapy for individuals with Parkinson's disease. The secondary outcome measures will add to our understanding of the impact of the therapy on overall health and well-being, as well as the potential for the Ekso to reduce fall-related incidents.

groundtruth: Of course! The secondary outcome measures include several aspects of mobility and quality of life. Let's go through each one. The first secondary outcome measure is "Gait speed-10MWT." This measure focuses on assessing the effect of Ekso facilitated training on gait speed in PWPD using the 10 Meter Walk Test (10MWT). We will measure improvements in gait speed in meters per second.

Gait speed will be assessed at multiple time points, including baseline, re-evaluation (5 weeks), discharge (8 weeks), and follow-up (20 weeks). This allows us to evaluate the sustained effects of the Ekso therapy on gait speed over time.

The other secondary outcome measures are "Gait endurance-6MWT," "Dynamic balance," "Functional strength-5xSTS," "Quality of Life-WHOQOL-BREF," and "Fall risk." 

For "Gait endurance-6MWT," we will assess the change in meters walked during the six-minute walk test (6MWT). This measure helps us determine the effect of Ekso facilitated training on gait endurance.

For "Dynamic balance," we will use the Functional Gait Assessment (FGA) to assess improvements in dynamic balance. The FGA is measured on an ordinal scale ranging from 0 to 30.

"Functional strength-5xSTS" focuses on evaluating the effect of Ekso facilitated training on functional strength in PWPD. We will measure the time taken to complete the Five time sit to stand (5xSTS) assessment.

"Quality of Life-WHOQOL-BREF" will assess the effect of Ekso facilitated training on the participants' quality of life. We will measure improvements in the scaled score recorded in percentage using the World Health Organization- Quality of Life Brief (WHOQOL-BREF).

Lastly, "Fall risk" will be evaluated by measuring the changes in the Timed-up-and-go (TUG) score. This measure helps us assess the participants' risk of falls.

Similar to gait speed, the secondary outcome measures will be assessed at baseline, re-evaluation (5 weeks), discharge (8 weeks), and follow-up (20 weeks). This allows us to thoroughly evaluate the sustained effects of the Ekso therapy on gait endurance, dynamic balance, functional strength, quality of life, and fall risk.

Abstract:
This study aimed to investigate the effect of propofol combined with remifentanil and neuromuscular blockers on postoperative cognitive dysfunction (POCD) after elective surgery. A total of 60 patients who underwent elective surgery under general anesthesia were randomly divided into a control group and an observation group. The control group was administered propofol and remifentanil intravenous anesthesia, while the observation group was administered propofol combined with remifentanil and neuromuscular blockers. The incidences of POCD, as well as cognitive function, memory function, and pain in the two groups were compared. Additionally, the levels of S100B, BDNF, IL‐6, TNF‐α, and IL‐10 in serum were compared between the two groups. The results showed that the incidence of POCD in the observation group was significantly lower than that in the control group, and the two groups had no significant difference in the incidence of mild cognitive dysfunction (p>0.05). Compared with before the operation, the postoperative cognitive function and memory function of the two groups were significantly decreased, with no significant difference between the two groups (p>0.05). Compared with the control group, the observation group had significantly reduced postoperative pain, with no significant difference in the dose of postoperative analgesics (p>0.05). Compared with before the operation, the levels of S100B, IL‐6, and TNF‐α in serum were significantly increased in the two groups, while the level of IL‐10 was reduced. However, there was no significant difference in the levels of BDNF in serum after operation between the two groups (p>0.05). Compared with the control group, the observation group had decreased levels of S100B (p<0.05), and there was no significant difference in the levels of BDNF, IL‐6, TNF‐α, and IL‐10 between the two groups (p>0.05). In conclusion, propofol combined with remifentanil and neuromuscular blockers can effectively reduce the incidence of POCD after elective surgery, improve postoperative cognitive and memory functions, and al

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
In the trial, questionnaires on posttraumatic stress reactions and psychological functioning will be used, as well as functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) measurements and transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) in combination with electroencephalography (EEG). The aim is to find out whether the combination of the questionnaires, fMRI and TMS in combination with EEG can be promising for the treatment of PTSD.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a psychological stress disorder. People who developed PTSD, have experienced or witnessed an event with an overwhelming threat to one' s life. During the traumatic event, such as a war zone injury, they have experienced fear, a sense of helplessness, or a combination of these feelings. After the event, people with PTSD have flashbacks, nightmares, and other stressful events to relive in response to triggers that were reminiscent of the initial traumatic event. One of the most important factors that explains the presence of PTSD is the way the brain processes emotional information. However, little research exists about the relationship between brain response to emotionally negative stimuli and PTSD. Our study in healthy individuals demonstrated that the brain processes negative information faster than positive information. People with PTSD also process negative information in a certain part of the brain faster than positive information. PTSD research has shown that PTSD-specific therapies are often accompanied by a reduction in PTSD symptoms. However, there is still a large group of patients who do not respond sufficiently to the current standard of care. New ways of treatment have therefore been sought in the field of psychiatry and a new promising treatment has been added to the Dutch standard of care since 2019, the magnetic seizure (TMS) device, a technique that has already shown promising results in multiple sclerosis and schizophrenia. The aim of our study is 1. To find out if TMS therapy causes changes in the brain response to traumatic stories compared to trauma-free stories, using a combination of questionnaires and fMRI measurements. 2. To find out if TMS therapy in people with PTSD leads to faster processing of positive information compared to negative information 3

Comparison of the diagnostic performance of the 11C-Fe_CIT method with two methods of ROI and SPM voxel-based analysis.

Intervention type
=================
Other

Primary outcome measure
=================
The primary outcome measure will be the accuracy of PET examination in staging patients with Parkinson's disease. We will use ROI and SPM voxel-based analysis methods to measure the levels of dopamine receptors (D2 and D3) and to calculate the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) in various regions of the brain (including the striatum, putamen, and caudate nucleus). We will consider patients with low dopamine receptor levels or low SNR values as having advanced Parkinson's disease.

Secondary outcome measures
=================
Comparison of the sensitivity and specificity of the two analysis methods (individual voxels and ROI), in the early diagnosis of Parkinson (PD) and in the differential diagnosis between PD and parkinsonism (multiple system atrophy, progressive supranuclear palsy, and atypical parkinsonian syndromes).

Participant inclusion criteria
=================
1. Age above 18 years at the time of evaluation.
2. Diagnosis of sporadic Parkinson's disease (PD), multiple system atrophy (MSA), progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), or atypical parkinsonian syndromes (APS).
3. Modified H-Y stage 1, 3, 3.5 or 4.
4. The patient provided written

You're welcome. 11C-Fe_CIT PET examination with voxel-based analysis method has been shown to be a promising and accurate diagnostic tool for the early detection and diagnosis of Parkinson's disease and parkinsonism. By evaluating the uptake of the radioactive tracer at the level of individual voxels, we can obtain a 3D image of the brain and assess the distribution and uptake of the tracer with high precision and sensitivity. On the other hand, the conventional ROI method is a non-invasive and relatively simple technique that has been used for many years to assess brain disorders. Comparing the two methods will provide valuable insights into their diagnostic accuracy and utility in clinical practice. 

Both outcome measures are expected to show significant differences between patients with Parkinson's disease and parkinsonism. Patients with Parkinson's disease are expected to have a higher radiotracer uptake compared to the normal population, while patients with parkinsonism may have a lower or similar uptake. This information will be valuable in differentiating patients with Parkinson's from those with other neurological disorders. Similarly, we expect to see significant differences in the diagnostic accuracy of the two methods, with the voxel-based method offering greater sensitivity and accuracy compared to the conventional ROI method. 

The time frame for evaluating these outcome measures is 2 years, which is sufficient to observe the progression of patients' disease and their response to treatment. The two analysis methods used in this study ensure that the outcome measures are comprehensive and accurate, providing valuable insights into the diagnostic accuracy of PET examination with 11C-Fe_CIT in patients with Parkinson's disease and parkinsonism.

The measure description for TEAEs would be the presence of TEAEs, SAEs, and lab abnormalities, according to the National Cancer Institute (NCI) Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) Version 5.0. We will assess TEAEs from the time the patient signs the informed consent form (ICF) up to 90 (+7) days after the last dose of SOT201. This assessment will be conducted approximately up to 3 years.

For the secondary outcome measures, I propose the following measures based on the trial's objectives. We should include the characterization of the area under the curve (AUClast, AUCinf, AUCtau) of SOT201, as well as the characterization of the maximum concentration (Cmax), time to maximum concentration (Tmax), and pre-dose concentration (Ctrough) of SOT201. These measures will provide valuable pharmacokinetic data on the drug's exposure levels and absorption characteristics. Additionally, we should consider measures such as objective response rate (ORR), duration of response (iDoR), clinical benefit rate (iCBR), progression-free survival (iPFS), and incidence of anti-drug antibodies (ADAs) against SOT201. These measures will help us evaluate the drug's efficacy, disease control, and immunogenicity. What are your thoughts on these suggestions?

Certainly! Here are the details for each secondary outcome measure:

1. Characterization of area under the curve (AUClast, AUCinf, AUCtau) of SOT201: This measure will be calculated using the trapezoidal method during a dosing interval (tau). We will assess AUC values from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17.) until cycle 20.

2. Characterization of maximum concentration (Cmax) of SOT201: We will monitor the maximum plasma concentration observed from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17.) until cycle 20.

3. Characterization of time to maximum concentration (Tmax) of SOT201: This measure will assess the time taken for the drug to reach its maximum plasma concentration. We will evaluate Tmax from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17..) until cycle 20.

4. Characterization of pre-dose concentration (Ctrough) of SOT201: We will measure the pre-dose trough SOT201 concentrations from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17..) until cycle 20.

5. Objective response rate (ORR): This measure will assess the proportion of patients who have a confirmed complete response (CR) or a partial response (PR), as the best overall response (BOR) determined by the Investigator as per the Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) v1.1. We will evaluate ORR from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted for up to approximately 3 years.

6. Duration of response (iDoR): iDoR is defined as the time from the first documented evidence of confirmed CR or PR until progressive disease (PD) determined by the Investigator per RECIST 1.1 or death from any cause, whichever occurs first. We will assess iDoR from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted up to approximately 3 years.

7. Clinical benefit rate (iCBR): This measure will include confirmed CR or PR at any time or stable disease (SD) of at least 6 months determined by the Investigator per RECIST 1.1. We will evaluate iCBR from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted for up to approximately 3 years.

8. Progression-free survival (iPFS): iPFS is defined as the time from the date of the first administration of SOT201 to the date of the first documented disease progression determined by the Investigator as per RECIST 1.1 or death from any cause, whichever occurs first. We will assess iPFS from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted for up to approximately 3 years.

9. Incidence of anti-drug antibodies (ADAs) against SOT201: We will assess the incidence of patients with anti-drug antibodies from Day 1 until 30 (±2) days after the last dose of SOT201.

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Incidence of hypoxemia: This measure assesses the peripheral oxygen saturation (≤90%) after inducing deep sedation during endoscopy. The time frame is from the induction of deep sedation to the end of the procedure.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Duration of intervention: Total time taken for the endoscopy procedure (in seconds).
- Duration of hypoxemia: Time between hypoxemia (<90% SpO2) and recovery (>90% SpO2) (in seconds).
- Hypoxemic events: Number of hypoxemic events per intervention/endoscopy.
- Hypoxemia duration to procedure duration: Relative ratio of hypoxemia duration compared to the total procedure duration.
- Airway intervention: Incidence of airway interventions such as mask ventilation, intubation, or interruption.
- Sedation score: Modified observer's assessment of Alertness/Sedation (MOAA/S).
- Endtidal CO2 (carbon dioxide): Continuous measurement of endtidal CO2 via the mask.

Abstract:
Study Purpose: To evaluate long‐term mechanical ventilation (LTMV) support in the ALS population and analyze its effects on quality of life (QOL). Patients and Methods: We conducted a 6‐month prospective study in which 16 patients with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) underwent LTMV support. The results were evaluated with a descriptive statistical analysis and statistical hypothesis testing. Clinical, QOL, and outcome‐related variables were compared before and after LTMV. The study was approved by the ethical committee of the Autonomous University of Barcelona. Results: The mean±standard deviation duration of LTMV support was 102.1±70.8 days (average duration of mechanical ventilator assistance: 692.4 ± 1041.2 minutes). Median survival was 866 days with longterm survival. A total of 9 subjects presented an improvement (+ median 4.25 points) in the ALS Assessment Question Score (ALSAQ)‐5. This was mainly because of an improvement in the "dyspnea" and "communication" variables of the questionnaire. There are no significant changes in total respiratory insufficiency questionnaire (RISQ) or severe respiratory insufficiency questionnaire (SIRSQ) scores. Conclusion: LTMV support can improve QOL measures but is associated with a high number of respiratory events. © 2020 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.

Abstract:
PURPOSE: To investigate the efficacy and safety of intravitreal ranibizumab in wet choroidal neovascularization.METHODS: This study was designed as a prospective, multi‐center, randomized clinical study, including 69 patients. Twenty‐five patients received a single intravitreal injection, 23 patients received three injections at treatment interval of 1 month and 21 patients received three injections at treatment interval of 4 weeks. Best‐corrected visual acuity (BCVA) and central retinal thickness (CRT) were measured before and after therapy in all the patients.RESULTS: The injection frequency (1 month vs. 4 weeks) had no effect on visual outcome and central retinal thickness. At month 3, both treatment modalities produced a significant decrease in central retinal thickness (P < 0.05). The mean ( +/‐ SD) increase of BCVA was +0.24 ( +/‐ 0.06) letters in the ranibizumab group and +0.15 ( +/‐ 0.09) letters in the bevacizumab group (P = 0.07), but this difference was not significant.CONCLUSION: Based on the results of this study, the effect of increasing the injection interval from 1 to 4 months may not affect the visual outcome and foveal thickness in wet choroidal neovascularization patients treated with ranibizumab. However, the present study included only a small number of patients (without subgroup analysis according to the presence or absence of exudative retinal detachment), and a future prospective randomized controlled study might be required to confirm the clinical significance of this observation.
