Abstract:
Chronic pain is a common problem in patients with addiction. It can be a result of prolonged substance use or the result of a primary syndrome. Many patients with addiction also suffer from chronic pain. However, there are few studies on patients with chronic pain in patients with addiction. This may be due to the fact that pain management in this context is complex and requires a multidisciplinary approach. Moreover, the prevalence of chronic pain and opioid use disorder is high in patients with opioid use disorder. The prevalence of chronic pain in chronic pain can be between 70 and 82%, depending on the assessment instrument and the definition of chronic pain. According to the International Association for the Study of Pain chronic pain is defined as a persistent and recurring pain that has lasted longer than three to six months. The experience of pain affects different aspects of life: personal and family life, employment, physical activity, quality of life, general health, and morbidity. This can lead to financial and emotional burdens. In the literature, the prevalence of chronic pain and opioid use disorder is low and varies by study population, age, and gender. A recent study found that 40% of patients with chronic pain had a high level of pain, and 9% of patients with chronic pain had a high level of disability. The study of pain in patients with substance use disorders is particularly relevant in the context of the management of pain, because opioids are one of the most commonly used drugs in the treatment of pain, and because pain has been postulated as a risk factor for relapse into drug use.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: The aim of the study was to evaluate the efficacy of pectoralis minor trigger point on shoulder pain in recreational sports women.METHODS: The study randomized 60 female subjects, with pain in the upper region, to two groups: manual therapy and posture and shoulder muscle strengthening exercises. There were two evaluation moments: at the beginning of the protocol and at 60 days. The following measurements were performed: pain evaluation; kinesiophobia evaluation (TSK); range of motion; strength of lower and upper trapezius, serratus anterior and pectoralis minor muscles; ultrasound evaluation of pectoralis minor. The statistical analysis was performed using Mann‐Whitney and Wilcoxon's tests. Chi‐square test was used for categorical data.RESULTS: Both groups had statistical improvement of symptoms in all evaluations, except for pectoralis minor thickness; there was no difference between groups.CONCLUSIONS: Both treatments showed excellent results for the treatment of pain and improvement of kinesiophobia. The exercises had an additional benefit for pectoralis minor.

Abstract:
The present study aims to determine the effect of a one‐month, 3xweek, progressive running program on the bone strength and blood biochemical markers of bone health and inflammation in postmenopausal osteopenic females (65.22 ± 4.06 years). The experimental group (EG) followed the mentioned running protocol for 4 weeks. At baseline and after two and four weeks, the femoral neck and tibial cortical and cancellous bone mineral density (BMD), bone strength index (BSI) and shear modulus (SM) were measured by peripheral quantitative computed tomography (pQCT); biomarkers of bone metabolism and muscle strength were evaluated as secondary outcome. After 4 weeks, BSI and SM significantly increased in EG, while total hip BMD (tH BMD) and total hip T‐score decreased (p<0.05). A significant interaction for tH BMD(T‐score) and BSI was found at the end of the exercise program (p=0.049). BSI (r=0.629) and SM (r=0.414) correlated positively with tH BMD and T‐score, respectively (p<0.05). The EG showed a significant improvement in the levels of N‐telopeptide (NTx) and C‐terminal telopeptide of type 1 collagen (CTX‐1) in the blood (p<0.05), suggesting that the postmenopausal females had lower bone resorption, while no significant interaction was observed in CTX‐1 and P1NP levels (p>0.05). Finally, these results suggest that the progressive running program may improve bone strength in postmenopausal osteopenic females through a decrease in the rate of bone turnover. Clinical Trial registration: ClinicalTrials.gov identifier: NCT04298430.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim is to evaluate the effectiveness of a rehabilitation program with exercise training based on cardiovascular autonomic nervous system modulation for improving physical functions in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

Detailed Description
-----------------
People with COPD often show functional decline related to cardiovascular autonomic dysfunction. In recent years, studies have shown that autonomic dysfunction in patients with COPD is associated with more serious functional decline and poor functional capacity. This indicates that autonomic dysfunction is a useful tool for understanding and evaluating the severity of COPD. Therefore, it is necessary to develop rehabilitation methods for the management of COPD that also consider autonomic dysfunction. In this regard, the investigators aim to compare the effects of an exercise training therapy based on cardiovascular autonomic dysfunction with conventional rehabilitation therapy in patients with COPD. Additionally, the investigators will examine the effects of autonomic dysfunction on functional capacity and respiratory capacity in patients with COPD.

Official Title
-----------------
Effects of Exercise Training With Autonomic Modulation in Subjects With Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease

Conditions
-----------------
Autonomic Dysfunction, Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease, Rehabilitation

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Behavioral: exercise training based on autonomic modulation

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The objective of this study is to provide investigators using the 3D Acoustic Holography system with an evaluation of the sonogenicity of the SonoWand (TM), for use in transdermal therapy applications and provide the investigator with a quantitative sonogenicity metric to assess the performance of the device.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Hologic, Inc. (hereinafter, Hologic, Inc.), is developing for investigational use, a non-invasive, ultrasonic, transdermal therapy device. The device enables transdermal non-invasive delivery of acoustic energy through the skin to modulate local blood flow and thermal tissue response in the tissue beneath the skin. This acoustic energy is generated by a sonogenic device that provides an energy profile that can be manipulated to allow a pre-determined delivery of the appropriate amount of energy for a desired response. The energy transducer (device probe) used to carry the ultrasonic energy through the skin surface is called a SonoWand. Hologic, Inc. has designed, developed, prototyped and validated a 26 mm diameter prototype version of the device. The investigational use of the device is through the use of a SonoWand that is placed in contact with the subject's skin and connected to an ultrasonic therapy device. The system is designed to deliver multiple frequencies of energy at set dwell times, with the goal of delivering sufficient non-invasive energy at the desired tissue depth and energy per pulse to result in a modulation of local blood flow response at the tissue location corresponding to the SonoWand contact location. Currently, the device is indicated for general and breast research use. The investigational use of the device is approved under the FDA Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) Guidance. The study is a non-therapeutic assessment of the SonoWand to be used in conjunction with the System Ultrasound Therapy device to determine the sonogenicity delivered to the skin and the tissue below the skin through use of the SonoWand. Introduction
=================
Knee osteoarthritis (OA) is a degenerative disease that mainly affects the elderly, affecting 30 to 50% of older adults. Knee OA is the leading cause of pain and disability in the elderly and is associated with a decrease in quality of life, increased mortality, and increased economic burden for patients and society. The key to treating this disease is pain relief, functional improvement, and delay or prevention of disability and disease progression. According to the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) guidelines, the first line of treatment for knee OA is non-pharmacological treatments, such as physical therapy and weight loss to reduce pressure on the knee. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are recommended as first-line pharmacological therapy in the absence of contraindications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or allergies, and when the non-pharmacological approach is insufficient. However, due to the side effects of long-term use of NSAIDs, including gastrointestinal bleeding and renal insufficiency, patients often have difficulty with long-term use. Alternative Therapies can fill this gap and are widely accepted by patients with different attitudes towards medication use, reducing the associated side effects and improving the quality of life of patients with knee OA. There is insufficient evidence for many alternative modalities, such as acupuncture and electrotherapy, and evidence-based medicine demonstrates that they can reduce pain and increase flexibility, functional improvement, and quality of life. Therefore, clinical guidelines recommend a multimodal treatment approach for knee osteoarthritis.
Acupuncture has been used to treat knee osteoarthritis in traditional Chinese medicine for many years. Modern studies have found that the effect of acupuncture on pain relief, disease progression, and quality of life in patients with knee OA is similar to that of NSAIDs and other pain-relieving drugs, which can reduce the side effects of drugs. In addition, acupuncture has been found to regulate the secretion of inflammatory factors and related cytokines to reduce pain after weight-bearing exercise, enhance functional exercise, improve patient self-care

Abstract:
Background: The purpose of this study was to investigate the effectiveness of auricular acupressure used along with routine acupuncture for the treatment of migraine in children. Methods: Children between 6 and 16 years of age were selected and randomly assigned to acupressure and nonacupressure groups. The primary endpoint was the number of migraines during the 21‐week trial. Secondary outcomes included the reduction of migraine intensity and duration, and the frequency of migraine drug use. Results: Seventy‐six children participated in the study. The mean age was 11.3 years (± 2.1 yrs) and the median age was 11.0 years. In the acupressure group, 17 of 38 (44.7%) participants were boys and in the nonacupressure group 18 of 38 (47.4%) were boys. The primary endpoint was recorded in 23.7% of patients in the acupressure group and 42.1% in the nonacupressure group (Odds Ratio = 0.355, 95% CI: 0.049‐2.950, p value = 0.442). Secondary endpoints were not significantly different between groups. Conclusions: A preliminary study suggests that acupressure does not enhance the treatment of children with migraine. However, the results indicate that it is a well tolerated alternative. It should be emphasized that these children received acupressure for only 6 months. A longer follow‐up may provide more information on the effectiveness of acupressure in the treatment of pediatric migraine.

The purpose of this observational study is to evaluate the clinical outcomes and risk factors of patients with chronic spontaneous urticaria (CSU). CSU is a common skin disease characterized by the recurrence of wheals and itch for more than 6 weeks, with unknown etiology. The prevalence of CSU in the general population is about 0.5% to 1%. The main clinical manifestation is wheals, with or without accompanying itching. The pathogenesis of chronic urticaria is complex, and the treatment methods involved are mainly inducible allergic drugs, non-sedating antihistamines and targeted therapy, such as C1 esterase inhibitor therapy. At present, there is no standard treatment for chronic urticaria, and it is still a challenge to control CSU well. In terms of treatment, most researchers believe that long-term treatment effects are better, but they have not reached a consensus on whether to add inducible allergic drugs. Long-term treatment with non-sedating antihistamines may cause recurring attacks of urticaria, so there is a certain risk in long-term treatment. In addition, targeted treatment for chronic spontaneous urticaria is effective in a short period of time, and some patients with chronic urticaria need to take medicine for a long time, but no evidence has been found that long-term use of this drug can improve the quality of life of patients, but it has been found that long-term use of this drug can increase the risk of adverse events (such as nasal bleeding, malaise and dry mouth). This study aims to establish an observational study cohort for patients with CSU and analyze the clinical efficacy of the current treatment regimen, risk factors related to the disease, and predictors of prognosis. Introduction
=================
Essential tremor (ET) is the most prevalent tremor disorder worldwide, affecting an estimated 7 million people in the United States alone (1). It is characterized by action tremor, which worsens with voluntary movement and improves with rest. There are many hypotheses about the cause of the tremor including alterations in cerebral oscillations, an imbalance between neuronal excitability and inhibition, and corticospinal disinhibition. Current treatment options for ET are limited. Pharmacotherapy can be effective in about 50% of patients but only controls tremor in 10-40% of patients, and the adverse effects limit the tolerability of these agents.(2) Surgical options offer more benefit, but the lack of long-term studies, possible side effects, and the high up-front cost of surgery make them less attractive. A number of non-surgical adjunctive therapies are under investigation, and one such modality is repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS).

Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: To compare, among patients with heart failure or peripheral arterial disease randomized to cardiac rehabilitation (CR) and home‐based exercise training (HBET), the effect on health‐related quality of life (HRQoL) and self‐reported activity. METHODS AND RESULTS: Cardiac rehabilitation randomized 75 (47 women, 68% white) patients with either heart failure (48%) or peripheral arterial disease (52%) to CR or HBET. HRQoL was assessed using the Minnesota Living With Heart Failure Questionnaire (MLWHFQ), the Medical Outcomes Study Short Form (SF‐36) questionnaire, and the Self‐Administered PAQ Plus questionnaire at baseline and 6 and 12 months. There were significant differences in the MLWHFQ scores, the SF‐36, and the Self‐Administered PAQ Plus scores for all comparisons between participants receiving CR and HBET for all time periods. The participants on the combined score (MLWHFQ, SF‐36, and Self‐Administered PAQ Plus) for both groups demonstrated a worsening of the score from baseline to months 6 and 12. CONCLUSION: Home‐based exercise training compared with cardiac rehabilitation results in a decrease in participation in physical activity and a worse HRQoL among patients with heart failure or peripheral arterial disease. There may be other reasons (for example, adverse events or disease trajectory) for these adverse effects among patients on the home‐based exercise training.

Effects of 48 Hours vs. 72 Hours of Postoperative Exercises in the Recovery of the Knee in Total Hip Arthroplasty Patients: a Randomized Clinical Trial

Abstract:
Purpose The aim of this prospective randomized study was to compare the recovery of the knee in patients submitted to total hip arthroplasty. Methods Between 2017 and 2018, 50 patients with primary osteoarthritis were included in this trial. One team performed routine medical treatment and performed a continuous passive motion (CPM) up to 72 hours postoperatively. A knee range of motion of 0°–90° was allowed. The second group was treated with routine medical treatment and allowed to sit up after 24 hours and stand up after 48 hours postoperatively and was also instructed to perform CPM up to 48 hours. The pain intensity in the knee and hip, pain medication consumption, time needed to achieve 90° of knee flexion, and knee and hip flexion and extension range of motion (ROM) were evaluated at week 1, 3, and 6 follow‐up. The data were analyzed with the IBM SPSS Statistics 11 for Windows (IBM, Armonk, New York, USA) and the level of statistical significance was defined as p < 0.05. Results The groups were similar in terms of age, weight, and side operated (p > 0.05). The 72‐hour CPM group had lower pain scores for knee extension than the 48‐hour CPM group (p= 0.047) between surgery and postoperative day 5. All patients demonstrated a range of motion of 0°–90° from day 1 to 6 in both groups. Conclusion This study demonstrated that the application of CPM up to 72 hours postoperatively in the recovery of knee ROM and decreased pain is clinically equivalent to a duration as short as 48 hours of postoperative patient mobilization.

Abstract:
Nuclear scanning methods have not been useful in staging non‐small‐cell lung cancer, but in this study, 140 thoracic scintigrams were examined for 49 patients in attempt to correlate the degree of perfusion and uptake of labeled colloid particles with histologic and radiographic findings. Fourteen scintigraphic studies were recorded as positive for metastases, most of which were localized to the lower lobes. Thirteen of these 14 had definite histologic evidence of tumor. A total of 33 studies were recorded as negative for metastatic disease; 31 of these were proven to be free of cancer, and two revealed a single metastatic lesion that was missed by the scintigraphic examination. In 53% of the patients with multiple pulmonary and nodal metastases, only one localization was observed on nuclear scanning methods; however, three or more were located in 82% of patients with more than one metastasis. With these methods, the metastases were missed most frequently in patients with large nodal masses; however, in such cases the results were not significantly inferior to those observed by means of conventional scintigraphic techniques. For most patients with advanced bronchogenic carcinoma undergoing curative resection, nuclear scanning methods provide information which is comparable to that obtained by thoracotomy but with less trauma.

It has shown good reliability and validity in people with osteoarthritis, and we can administer it at 9 weeks and 3 months. The fifth measure is the International Physical Activity Questionnaire (IPAQ.). This questionnaire assesses the amount of vigorous-intensity physical activity, moderate-intensity physical activity, and walking activity undertaken in the past seven days. It has shown good reliability and validity in people with knee osteoarthritis, and we can administer it at 9 weeks and 3 months. We can use the data from the IPAQ. to assess participants' total physical activity level and to determine their overall physical activity patterns.

Absolutely. Let's go through the secondary outcome measures one by one. The first measure is the Brief Pain Inventory - Numeric Rating Scale. This measure assesses pain intensity by asking about worst and least pain intensity in the past 24 hours, pain on average, and pain right now. It uses an 11-point scale, with zero representing 'no pain' and 10 representing the 'worst imaginable pain'. This measure has been shown to have excellent reliability and validity in people with knee osteoarthritis. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks and 3 months.

The next measure is the Modified Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI). This measure assesses the presence of comorbidities in participants, including knee osteoarthritis. The CCI has been widely used in various patient populations, including knee osteoarthritis. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks and 3 months.

The next measure is endogenous pain modulation, which assesses the efficiency of pain modulation mechanisms in individuals with knee osteoarthritis. We can use the conditioned pain modulation (CPM) testing method to evaluate this measure. By assessing the ascending measure of pressure pain threshold (PPT) at the anterior shin and the conditioning stimulus in the form of forearm ischemia, we can calculate the percent efficiency of CPM (%CPM) as PPT2/PPT1 multiplied by 100. This measure can provide insights into the neurobiological effects of the intervention. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks.

The other secondary outcome measures include pain interference, pain catastrophizing, Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS), Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS), multi-joint pain assessed through a body diagram, knee awareness, functional leg strength, medication use, adverse events, patient global impression of change, blinding effectiveness, usefulness of the program for managing knee OA, frequency of the program, duration of the program, acceptability of the delivery of the brain stimulation, acceptability of the delivery of the yoga session of the program, likelihood of recommending the program to others with knee OA, burdensomeness of completing questionnaires and physical assessments, adherence rate, and rate of completion of home sessions. Each of these measures serves a specific purpose and provides valuable information on various aspects of the intervention and study outcomes.

Abstract:
Immediate post‐operative pain 12 and 24 h after primary total hip arthroplasty (THA) is reported as a relevant patient outcome measure. Pain reduction is associated with decreased need for post‐operative analgesia and reduced morbidity, and might potentially decrease the risk of surgical site infections and deep vein thrombosis. We therefore aim to examine whether there is a relation between post‐operative pain intensity after primary THA and patient age. Pain was assessed with Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) at different time points (2h, 8h, 22h, 24h) after surgery. We included 120 consecutive patients undergoing primary THA, and found a statistically significant relation between age and pain scores (P < 0.0001), with older patients reporting less pain than younger patients. We propose that older patients might, therefore, be less affected by immediate post‐operative pain, and might thereby need less post‐operative pain medication and hence possibly face less risk of post‐operative complications. As post‐operative pain is currently not routinely assessed we cannot, in this study, assess whether there is a causal relation between post‐operative pain and post‐operative complications. However, we argue that a multimodal analgesic approach including opioids, NSAIDs, gabapentinoids, paracetamol, local infiltration and continuous wound infiltration might decrease post‐operative pain and should be the method of choice.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
A multicentre prospective study for measuring the safety, efficacy, and feasibility of the combined use of PSMA-PET/CT and TEP-PET/CT for patients with prostatic disease. There is a substantial evidence base for the accuracy of PSMA PET/CT scanning for initial staging of prostatic cancer. TEP PET/CT has not been evaluated but there is in vitro and animal evidence that choline is taken up by prostate cancer cells. To the researchers' knowledge, this study is a world-first.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study is designed as a prospective trial. A total of 50 patients will be randomised and undergo a PET/CT scan with both PSMA and Choline tracers. Follow up will be for prostate-specific antigen, disease recurrence, and death within 5 years. If the trial demonstrates potential then further follow up will be for 10 years for the purposes of patient survival. If the trial indicates superior efficacy of the combined tracers, then there is also potential to extend this to more centres in the future.

Abstract:
RATIONALE: Pregnane X receptor (PXR) may be a potential target for treatment of prostate cancer. PURPOSE: The purpose of this phase II study was to assess the efficacy and toxicity of brivanib and enzalutamide in patients with prostate cancer.PATIENTS AND METHODS: Forty‐two patients with metastatic androgen‐independent prostate cancer were treated with enzalutamide and brivanib in a 2:1 ratio. The median change from the baseline for prostate‐specific antigen (PSA) after 12 weeks was ‐66.2% (95% confidence interval [CI], 90.2% to 100.0%). There were two partial responses and three patients who had a decrease in PSA greater than 50%. The most commonly reported adverse events were increased lipase (92.9%), fatigue (83.3%), increased amylase (76.2%), muscle spasms (58.1%), and nausea (42.9%). Abstract:

Postoperative bleeding in neurosurgical patients is a common complication that can lead to serious morbidity and mortality. Transfusion of allogeneic blood can be associated with adverse effects on patient outcomes. Tranexamic acid (TXA) has been shown to be an effective and safe agent in reducing postoperative bleeding. The recommended dosage regimen for TXA varies depending on the route of administration. There is a paucity of literature on the role of TXA in neurosurgical patients. This double‐blind, randomized, controlled clinical trial aimed to compare two different dosage regimens of intravenous TXA infusion in neurosurgical patients. In this study, we assigned 200 neurosurgical patients requiring supratentorial/intraventricular/infratentorial brain surgery to one of two groups: one group received a 10mg/kg bolus of TXA followed by an infusion of 1gr/hr for 8 hours, while the other group received 10 mg/kg of TXA at the end of surgery and repeated infusions of 1gr/hr for 8 hours. The primary outcome measure was the maximal amplitude of the clot reaction time (CRT) test. Secondary outcome measures included the reaction time (r‐time) of the clot kinetics (CK) test, the alpha angle of the CK test, the maximal lysis of the CRT test, the maximal amplitude of the clot formation function (CFF) test, serum hemoglobin value, number of units of transfused packed RBC, fresh frozen plasma, cryoprecipitate, and platelet within 6 hours, the incidence of postoperative seizure within 48 hours, the incidence of postoperative thromboembolic events within 48 hours, the amount of bleeding from surgical drains within 48 hours, and the incidence of re‐operation due to postoperative bleeding within 48 hours. Including these measures will provide a comprehensive assessment of the impact of different TXA administration strategies on various aspects of coagulation, bleeding, seizures, thromboembolic events, and postoperative outcomes. Let's summarize the outcome measures we have so far:

Primary Outcome Measure:
1. CRT maximal amplitude: This measure assesses the maximal amplitude of the CRT test, reflecting the overall coagulation profile of the patient within 24 hours.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. CK reaction time: The value of the r-time of the CK test.
2. CK alpha angle: The value of the alpha angle of the CK test.
3. CRT maximal lysis: The value of maximal lysis of the CRT test.
4. CFF maximal amplitude: The value of maximal amplitude of the CFF test.
5. Hemoglobin: Serum hemoglobin value.
6. Packed RBC: Number of units of transfused packed RBC within 6 hours.
7. Fresh frozen plasma: Number of units of transfused fresh frozen plasma within 6 hours.
8. Cryoprecipitate: Number of units of transfused cryoprecipitate within 6 hours.
9. Platelet: Number of units of transfused platelet (apheresis) or platelet concentrate within 6 hours.
10. Seizure: Incidence of postoperative seizure within 48 hours.
11. Thromboembolism: Incidence of postoperative myocardial infarction, cerebral infarction, pulmonary thrombosis, and intestinal infarction within 48 hours.
12. Postoperative bleeding: Amount of bleeding from surgical drains within 48 hours.
13. Re-operation: Incidence of re-operation due to postoperative bleeding within 48 hours.

Intervention Description:: The intervention is called "Peer Connect: Expanding Social Networks to Reduce Social Isolation and Improve Health Outcomes for Older Adults" and it will be delivered to all study participants in a single group. The objective of this intervention program is to improve social networks, social support, and health outcomes by connecting socially disadvantaged older adults with cancer to lay navigators to provide social and emotional support during the COVID-19 pandemic.
The intervention involves a structured training program for community representative lay navigators based on an existing intervention called Peer Connect. The intervention will be divided into two components: group training and role-play practice.
During the group training, the lay navigators will receive training on the roles and responsibilities of lay navigators, communication skills, cultural competence, conflict resolution, and the process of building social networks. The training will be led by a health psychologist and a licensed social worker.
After the group training, the lay navigators will have an opportunity to practice their skills through role-play with volunteer older adults and community representatives. The role-plays will be recorded and reviewed to provide feedback and improve the lay navigators' performance.

1) Disease control rate (DCR) by RECIST1.1 and PCWG3 criteria per investigators' review: This measures the percentage of participants with confirmed best overall response of CR, PR, or stable disease (SD) per investigators' review, and provides insights into a drug's effectiveness in controlling tumor growth.
2) Duration of response (DoR) by RECIST1.1 and PCWG3 criteria per investigators' review: This measures the time from the first documented objective response to the first documented disease progression or death from any cause, whichever occurs first, and provides insights into how long a drug can effectively control the disease.
3) Time to objective response (TTR): TTR is defined as the time from the first study drug administration to the first documented objective response per RECIST1.1 and PCWG3 criteria per investigators' review. This provides insights into the speed at which a drug can exert its therapeutic effect on a patient's disease.
4) Several other measures related to PSA response, overall survival, and pharmacokinetics: These include the percentage of participants with a PSA response of PSA50, PSA ≥ 50%, or PSA < 1.0 ng/mL. Study design: The study will use a randomised, open-label, two-stage, adaptive, platform design.
Stage 1 objectives: To determine the safety of the study intervention.
Stage 1 participants may enter the study in sequential blocks of 40 participants, or 80 participants overall.
Stage 2 objectives: To determine the efficacy of the intervention in participants with oesophageal cancer who are considered too vulnerable to take part in a randomised clinical trial (RCT), and have no other therapeutic treatment options.
Stage 2 is only open via this study.

[inst] How is the study structured and how long will participants be followed for?

Stage 1: Participants will be followed up at screening, at the start of treatment, during the first cycle while they are still taking the study treatment (1, 3, and 5 weeks after the start of treatment), then at the end of the treatment (EoT), one month after the end of the treatment (1+1month) and 90 days after the end of the treatment (90+days).
Stage 2: Participants will be followed up for 90 days after the end of treatment. In stage 2 the treatment period will be adjusted according to the results of stage 1.

[inst] What is the study measuring?

Primary study outcome: For stage 1, the primary outcome measure to determine the safety of the study intervention will be measured by the proportion of participants with adverse events (AEs) attributable to the study treatment assessed at EoT. In stage 2, the primary study objectives are to investigate the clinical activity of the intervention in participants with oesophageal cancer and oesophagogastric junction adenocarcinoma (OGJAC) to a response rate (assessed by investigators) of at least 40% (clinical benefit) and to investigate the safety of the intervention in participants with oesophageal cancer and oesophagogastric junction adenocarcinoma, with adverse events in at least 50% of participants (AEs attributable to the intervention).

Secondary study objectives: In stage 1 of the study, secondary exploratory endpoint measures include safety and toler

Brief summary
=================
This study in prostate cancer is being conducted in a prospective, open-label, and multicenter design. The study will enroll a patient population at centers with a total of 700 patients. Patients will be assigned to one of two cohorts (Cohort 1 or Cohort 2) based on their planned antitumor therapy. Cohort 1 includes patients planning therapy with cytotoxic therapy, with or without an androgen receptor pathway inhibitor (ARPI). Cohort 2 includes patients planning therapy with androgen deprivation therapy (ADT), with or without an ARPI, and not planning cytotoxic therapy. Patients will receive an FDG/PET/CT scan at baseline and 12 weeks after the start of therapy to evaluate the effects of therapy on prostate cancer. The primary endpoint of the study is the overall percentage of patients in each cohort who achieve a complete metabolic response (CMR) at 12 weeks after the start of therapy. Secondary endpoints are the percentage of patients in each cohort who develop hormone-receptor progression-free survival (HRPFS), the percentage of patients free of clinical disease progression (PD1), and the percentage of patients who achieve a partial metabolic response (PMR) at 12 weeks after the start of therapy. This study will help determine the effectiveness of FDG/PET/CT for monitoring prostate cancer treatment.

Abstract:
To compare safety and efficacy of nivolumab vs. pembrolizumab in pre‐treated patients with metastatic non‐small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) from a population with a median number of prior therapy lines of 1. Methods: The phase 3 randomised open‐label trial enrolled patients with non‐small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), stage IIIB or IV, previously treated with at least one chemotherapy (CT) regimen and at least one prior immunosuppressive agent, including anti‐programmed death (PD)‐1/PD‐L1 inhibitors. Patients were randomised to receive nivolumab or pembrolizumab. A retrospective, post hoc analysis, including all patients randomised, was performed to describe overall safety. Results: As of 12th October 2017, 223 patients (57.9% males, median age 64.5, 26.4% current/former smoker, ECOG 0‐1, ≥ 50% tumour PD‐L1 staining in 50.7%, stage IV in 91.2%, 1 prior line of CT in 92.0%) were randomised to receive treatment with nivolumab (15.1%) or pembrolizumab (84.9%). Patients had similar clinical baseline characteristics and treatment history. Both agents were well tolerated. The most frequently reported adverse events (AEs) in the overall population were asthenia (30.1%), pyrexia (21.9%), nausea (13.8%) and vomiting (13.8%). Abstract:
Introduction: Extravasation of contrast medium during angiography can lead to skin and soft tissue damage due to direct toxicity and the immune response. Aims: This study aimed to compare two dressing methods for preventing contrast medium extravasation during angiography. Materials and Methods: In this single‐blinded randomized clinical trial, 50 patients undergoing diagnostic coronary angiography were randomly allocated to receive standard or modified compression dressings. Patients' sociodemographic characteristics, medical history, medication use, and symptoms of angina were documented. The presence of local skin and soft tissue reactions was assessed daily until the day of discharge. Results: The mean age of patients was 61.4 ± 9.3 years, and 33 (66%) were males. There was no significant difference between the two groups in terms of mean age and frequency of angina (P>0.05). Local skin and soft tissue reactions were significantly less prevalent in group1 (P<0.05). No significant difference was found between the two groups in terms of medication use (P>0.05). No adverse events were observed during the study period. Conclusion: The use of modified compression dressings significantly reduces the incidence of local skin and soft tissue reactions following diagnostic coronary angiography. These dressings are safe and can be recommended to prevent contrast‐induced extravasation.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Parameters of adequate ventilation and oxygenation: Monitoring the PaO2/FiO2 ratio and PaCO2 at regular intervals (1, 2, 3, 4, 8, 16, 24, 36, and 48 hours) to evaluate respiratory function.
- Sedation score using the Ramsay score: Assessing sedation levels every 8 hours for 48 hours using a scale ranging from 1 (agitated and uncomfortable) to 6 (asleep with no response to stimulation).

The first is the change from baseline in forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) over 1 year of treatment with Itepekimab. The second is the change in Health Assessment Questionnaire-Disability Index (HAQ-DI) scores over 1 year of treatment. The third is the change in St George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) scores over 1 year of treatment. These secondary outcome measures will provide valuable information on the efficacy of Itepekimab in improving lung function and quality of life in participants with COPD.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The primary objective of Part 1 of this study is to investigate the long-term safety and tolerability of repeat administration of 10 milligrams (mg) subcutaneous (SC) injections of Itepekimab every 2 weeks (Q2W) or 10 mg SC Q4W in participants with moderate COPD who have completed the treatment period of the clinical studies EFC16750 or EFC16819. The secondary objectives of Part 1 are to evaluate the efficacy of Itepekimab and determine its durability of effect, with the following secondary outcome measures: Change from baseline in forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) and Health Assessment Questionnaire-Disability Index (HAQ-DI) scores 12 months after the end of the treatment period in the parent studies. Part 2 of the study will enroll a sub-set of participants who were previously randomized in EFC16750 or EFC16819 into Part 1. The primary objective of Part 2 is to evaluate the immune response to COVID-19 infection. The secondary objective of Part 2 is to evaluate the long-term durability of effect in terms of changes in inflammatory markers over 12 months of treatment with Itepekimab. 9 participants who complete Part 2 of the study will participate in Part 3. The primary objective of Part 3 is to evaluate the long-term durability of Itepekimab after 14 weeks of treatment discontinuation.

Lastly, the change from Week 0 for CASA-Q will assess quality of life measures specific to COPD, including physical and mental health, as well as the ability to perform daily activities. Abstract
=================

Background
-----------------
Background: Intensive care unit patients frequently experience pain, a feeling of helplessness, and discomfort. The aim of this study is to investigate the impact of nursing care based on Kolcaba’s comfort theory on the comfort levels and satisfaction of intensive care patients. Materials and Methods: This is a prospective study with a single group intervention. A total of 160 ICU patients will be included in the study. The primary outcome measure is the patient’s self-report of their current level of comfort, measured using the General Comfort Scale. The secondary outcome measure is the patient’s self-report of their satisfaction with the quality of care received, measured using the Client Satisfaction Questionnaire (CSQ). The time frame for these measures is 24 hours after the start of patient participation in the study.

Title
=================
The effect of nursing care based on Kolcaba's comfort theory on the comfort, satisfaction, and sleep quality of intensive care patients

Scientific title
=================
The effect of nursing care based on Kolcaba's comfort theory on comfort, satisfaction, and sleep quality of intensive care patients

Plain English Summary
=================
The aim of this study is to investigate the effect of nursing care based on Kolcaba's Comfort Theory on the comfort, satisfaction, and sleep quality of intensive care patients. The study will be conducted in the intensive care unit (ICU) of a tertiary hospital. We will recruit 100 patients between the ages of 18 and 65 who meet the inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria. The intervention group will receive nursing care based on Kolcaba's Comfort Theory while the control group will receive standard care. The intervention will be conducted for a period of 48 hours, and the outcome measures will be assessed before and after the intervention. The primary outcome measure will be the comfort level of the patients, which will be assessed using the General Comfort Scale. The secondary outcome measures will include comfort behaviors, comfort numerical scale, and Richard-Campbell Sleep Scale. We expect to find a significant difference in the comfort level of the patients between the intervention and control groups, as well as an improvement in their satisfaction and sleep quality levels. This study will contribute to the development of evidence-based nursing care practices based on Kolcaba's Comfort Theory, which can improve the quality of care provided to intensive care patients.

groundtruth: Certainly! Let's start with the first outcome measure, retention. This measure evaluates the retention rate of the restorations using the United States Public Health Service criteria. It assesses any loss of restorative material. We'll need to evaluate retention from baseline to 24 months.

The scoring criteria for retention will be based on the United States Public Health Service criteria. We'll use the following scores: Alfa for no loss of restorative material, Charlie for any loss of restorative material. These scores will help us assess the effectiveness of the deep margin elevation technique in improving the stability and longevity of the restorations.

Marginal discoloration is an important measure to evaluate the sealing ability of the restorations and the presence of any gaps or defects at the restoration margins. We'll assess marginal discoloration using the modified United States Public Health Service criteria. The evaluation will be performed by two independent clinicians. The scores will be Alfa for no discoloration, Bravo for discoloration without penetration in pulpal direction, and Charlie for discoloration with penetration in pulpal direction. The evaluation will be conducted from baseline to 24 months.

Marginal adaptation focuses on the precision and fit of the restorations. We'll evaluate it using the modified United States Public Health Service criteria. Two independent clinicians will visually inspect the restorations with a mirror. The scores will be Alfa for closely adapted with no visible crevice, Bravo for a visible crevice where an explorer can penetrate, and Charlie for a crevice in which dentin is exposed. This evaluation will also be done from baseline to 24 months.

Secondary caries is an important consideration for the long-term success of restorations. We'll evaluate the presence of secondary caries using the United States Public Health Service criteria. The scores will be Alfa for no caries presented and Charlie for caries present. This evaluation will also be conducted from baseline to 24 months.

That's a great choice for a primary outcome measure. To measure the functional muscle power output of the leg, we can use the cycle sprint test. This test measures the maximum lower limb muscle power in Watts from three times 10-second maximal efforts. Higher values indicate better muscle power output. We can assess this outcome measure at different time points: preoperative, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think?

Absolutely! For measuring muscle strength, we can use the manual muscle testing (MMT) as a standardized measuring tool. The patient, in a sitting position with 20 degrees knee flexion, will be asked to actively extend the knee against resistance proximal to the ankle. We'll use the numeric score 0-5 from the Daniels and Worthingham Scale to assess quadriceps muscle strength. Higher values indicate better muscle strength. We can assess this outcome measure at preoperative, 48 hours after surgery, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What are your thoughts on this?

To measure mobility, we can use the timed up and go test (TUG). This test is a standardized measuring tool that times the patient's ability to rise from an armchair, walk to a line on the floor 3 meters away, turn, and walk back to the chair. Lower values on the TUG test indicate better mobility. We can assess this outcome measure at preoperative, 48 hours after surgery, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think?

For clinical results, we can include parameters such as redness, swelling, hyperthermia, wound/scar assessment, range of motion, stability, and adverse events. These parameters will provide a comprehensive evaluation of the clinical outcomes and potential complications associated with the surgery and nerve blocks. We can assess these clinical results at preoperative, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What are your thoughts on this?

To assess radiological results, we can use x-rays, including ap and lateral views, patella views, and whole leg axis views. These x-rays will help us evaluate the alignment of the leg, patella position, and overall leg axis. We can assess radiological results at preoperative, day 1 after surgery, 6 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think about this approach?

To measure pain control, we can use the numeric rating scale (NRS) ranging from 0 to 10, with lower values indicating better pain control. We can assess pain levels before surgery, twice daily on the ward (except for the first 6 hours: hourly), day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What are your thoughts on this measurement for pain control?

To document opioid consumption, we can keep a record of the administered drugs, including the name of the drug, dosage, and frequency of use. This documentation will help us evaluate the patterns of opioid consumption before surgery, during the hospital stay, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think about this approach?

To document the length of hospital stay, we can simply keep a record of the number of days the patient spends in the hospital. This will help us evaluate the duration of the hospital stay before surgery, during the hospital stay, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What are your thoughts on this approach?

For patient satisfaction, we can use two questionnaires: the Oxford Knee Score and EQ-5D-5L. The Oxford Knee Score is a questionnaire with a range of 12-60 points, with lower values indicating better satisfaction. The EQ-5D-5L questionnaire consists of 5 questions with 5 answers each, including EQ-VAS, which ranges from 0 to 100, with higher values indicating better satisfaction. We can assess patient satisfaction at preoperative, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think about this approach?

Primary Outcome Measure:

- Muscle strength: Manual muscle testing (MMT) using a numeric score 0-5 (Daniels and Worthingham Scale) to assess quadriceps muscle strength. This will be assessed at preoperative, 48 hours after surgery, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Mobility: Timed up and go test (TUG) to assess mobility. This will be assessed at preoperative, 48 hours after surgery, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.

- Pain control: Numeric rating scale 0-10 to assess pain levels. This will be assessed before surgery, twice daily on the ward (except for the first 6 hours: hourly), day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.

- Length of hospital stay: Documentation of the number of days in the hospital. This will be assessed before surgery, during hospital stay, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Patient satisfaction 1: Questionnaire (Oxford Knee Score) with a range of 12-60 points. This will be assessed at preoperative, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Patient satisfaction 2: Questionnaire (EQ-5D-5L) with 5 questions and EQ-VAS ranging from 0 to 100. This will be assessed at preoperative, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.

Abstract:
Introduction: The combination of hydroxychloroquine and CDK4/6 inhibitors may provide synergistic anti‐tumor effects in advanced solid tumors. However, the safety profile and optimal dosage of this combination therapy need to be evaluated in a clinical trial. Methods: This is an open‐label, single‐center, multicohort Phase Ib/II trial. Patients with advanced or metastatic HR+HER2‐breast cancer who have failed standard treatment will be enrolled. The first cohort will receive hydroxychloroquine at a dose of 600 mg twice daily and palbociclib at a dose of 60 mg twice daily. If no dose‐limiting toxicities (DLTs) are observed in the first cohort, the second cohort will receive hydroxychloroquine at a dose of 900 mg twice daily and palbociclib at a dose of 90 mg twice daily. The third cohort will receive hydroxychloroquine at a dose of 1200 mg twice daily and palbociclib at a dose of 120 mg twice daily. If DLTs are observed in ≥2 out of 3 patients in any cohort, enrollment in the next cohort will be stopped. The safety dose of the combination therapy will be determined based on the incidence of DLTs, and the recommended phase II dose will be the one with the best safety profile. The primary endpoint is the safety dose of the combination therapy, and the secondary endpoint is the recommended phase II dose, as determined by a DLT assessment. OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effectiveness of topical levobunolol in reducing the number of diurnal and nocturnal hypersensitive responses (HSRs) in pediatric patients with allergic asthma.METHODS: Fifteen children with allergic asthma were studied during a diurnal period of 4 hours (9:00 AM‐1 PM) at each of two visits to the Medical College of Georgia (MCG) Health Sciences Center Pediatric Allergy Clinic, followed by a second set of visits at night or in the early morning. During each visit, the children's vital signs, including peak expiratory flow (PEF), were noted prior to challenge. Following placebo challenge, the number of bronchoconstricting dose (BD) of shortacting beta2‐agonist (SABA) in a metered dose inhaler was then recorded. Levobunolol treatment of one eye was initiated 15 days prior to each challenge and continued until each group of challenges was completed. Each group lasted 2 weeks.RESULTS: During the diurnal placebo trials, the subjects required an average of 0.78 BD during the morning diurnal period. In the levobunolol treated eye, the subjects required an average of 0.58 BD (P < 0.03), during this same period. At night, the average BD during placebo trials was 1.49, and the number increased to 1.78 during the levobunolol trials (P < 0.22). In the morning, topical levobunolol significantly reduced the number of HSRs when compared with placebo trials (P = 0.045). The subjects reported less wheezing (P = 0.045) in the morning group when compared with the placebo group. Background and Aim: The current study aims to investigate the relationship between Cytokine Response to Cholesterol and Atherosclerosis (CYRCIA) and cardiovascular events in subjects with acute coronary syndrome. Methods: The present study was performed as a secondary analysis of three randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled trials. A total of 3343 patients diagnosed with acute coronary syndrome were randomized into three trials. One hundred and ninety‐two patients were selected based on a positive diagnosis for CYRCIA. The primary end point included the incidence of major adverse cardiovascular events, which primarily included cardiovascular death, non‐fatal myocardial infarction, and non‐fatal cardiac arrest. Results: The major adverse cardiovascular events of the 192 included patients were significantly higher than those of the 2482 patients not included (64.5% vs. 59.1%, P = 0.03). Among the 192 included patients, the number of major adverse cardiovascular events in patients with a single positive result was significantly higher than that in patients with negative or double negative results (P = 0.003). The CYRCIA result did not affect treatment efficacy or event incidence (P > 0.05). Conclusion: The results indicate that CYRCIA is not applicable for primary prevention in patients with acute coronary syndrome. Larger clinical trials are required to confirm these results. Copyright © 2019 Liu et al. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Intravitreal bevacizumab (IVB) has been shown to be a safe and effective treatment for neovascular age-related macular degenration (nAMD). Nevertheless, it is estimated that 10% of patients either have a poor response or a recurrence of intraretinal or subretinal fluid which necessitates additional monthly treatment and can eventually lead to blindness despite continuous monthly treatment with IVB. In the majority of these cases, the inflammatory response plays an important pathophysiological role in the development of neovascular activity and cystoid macular edema.

Detailed Description
-----------------
To date, the standard treatment is IVB monotherapy. Given the limited amount of fluid that can be sucked into the eye by IVB, the efficacy of IVB monotherapy can be limited. This can be further complicated in the presence of an elevated vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and an inflammatory response (as reflected by increased levels of c-reactive protein (CRP), serum amyloid protein a (SAA), vascular cell adhesion protein one (VCAM-1), intercellular cell adhesion molecule-1 (ICAM-1), interleukin - 6 (IL- 6), interleukin - 8 (IL-8), and tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNFα)). The hypothesis is that the presence of increased levels of inflammatory markers may result in a poor response to IVB monotherapy. Dexamethasone is a steroid which can suppress the inflammatory response and has good vitreous penetration, with a plasma elimination half-life of 36-54 hours and a vitreous half-life of 6-14 days. Dexamethasone 1.7mg (DEXy-Medrol) is currently FDA and European Union approved for the treatment of noninfectious uveitis of the posterior segment of the eye. Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Early detection of liver, biliary tract, and pancreatic cancers is crucial for successful treatment. Recent advancements in liquid biopsy techniques allow for the detection of cancers using circulating cell‐free DNA (cfDNA) methylation, serum protein, and microRNA. We aimed to develop a combined model to detect liver, biliary tract, and pancreatic cancers and assess its effectiveness in identifying different subtypes and stages of these cancers.METHODS: We retrospectively analyzed 336 participants (192 cases and 144 controls), comprising three sub‐studies: early detection of liver cancer, early detection of biliary tract cancer, and early detection of pancreatic cancer. Clinical information and related blood samples were collected from participants. Blood samples were used to extract cfDNA, and the DNA methylation patterns of tumor suppressor genes and oncogenes were investigated using genome‐wide DNA methylation analysis. Additionally, serum protein and microRNA levels were analyzed to develop the combined model. A comprehensive analysis combining the above methods was conducted to detect cancer in all study sub‐groups. Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves were used to evaluate the diagnostic performance of the model.RESULTS: The ROC curve analysis showed that the combined model exhibited an area under the curve (AUC) of 0.79 for early detection of liver cancer, 0.80 for early detection of biliary tract cancer, and 0.76 for early detection of pancreatic cancer. The sensitivity and specificity of the combined model were 64.3% and 71.4%, respectively, in detecting liver cancer, 69.2% and 67.9% in detecting biliary tract cancer, and 70.6% and 68.6% in detecting pancreatic cancer.CONCLUSIONS: The combined model demonstrates adequate diagnostic performance in identifying early liver, biliary tract, and pancreatic cancers. Its ability to detect different subtypes and stages of these cancers highlights its potential for early detection and monitoring.

Study
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The main purpose of the study is to assess the effectiveness and safety of a novel therapeutic approach (e.g. using a new drug) in patients with a certain disease or condition (e.g. lung cancer). The study will also investigate whether the novel treatment has any negative side effects on other organs or systems in the body. This will be achieved by monitoring the patient's health during the study and collecting data on any adverse events that they may experience. The study will also seek to determine whether the novel treatment can improve the patient's overall health or quality of life. To accomplish this, specific symptoms and functional abilities will be assessed before and after treatment.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a prospective, single-center, non-randomized, open-label, uncontrolled trial. This study will focus on the efficacy of thoracic radiation therapy (TRT) combined with stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) in patients with primary tumors and brain metastases, and will evaluate them mainly through radiographic and clinical characteristics. A total of 31 patients will be enrolled in this study. The inclusion criteria will include the following - histologically confirmed non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and brain metastases; patients require radiotherapy, but patients who only require medication can be excluded. The exclusion criteria will include active bleeding and uncontrolled bleeding diseases, serious complications or physical conditions that are not suitable for long-term follow-up, and mental illness or cognitive impairment that affects their judgment or understanding. The treatment process of the trial is shown in Figure 1. The first part is the selection and preliminary diagnosis of the case. The patient undergoes a full examination and diagnosis according to medical history and physical examination. The clinical staging and diagnosis of primary tumors are in line with the diagnosis and treatment guidelines formulated by the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN). In the second part, the patient underwent enhanced CT or enhanced MRI to determine whether the patient has single or multiple brain metastases. Before treatment,

Abstract:
PURPOSE: Concomitant chemoradiotherapy and neoadjuvant docetaxel are promising options in locally advanced non‐small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The aim of this study is to identify the best sequence for preoperative treatment.PATIENTS AND METHODS: Eligible patients will be assigned to groups: (1) sequential chemoradiotherapy followed by surgery and adjuvant docetaxel, (2) neoadjuvant docetaxel followed by surgery and concomitant chemoradiation, (3) concomitant chemoradiotherapy followed by neoadjuvant docetaxel, and (4) concomitant chemoradiotherapy followed by surgery and adjuvant docetaxel. Chemotherapy will be given in platinum‐based doublets. Radiotherapy will be delivered with 6‐MV photon beams delivered by a multileaf collimator, using a 3D conformal treatment planning with 2 fields on the 1st and the 5th week from the end of chemotherapy, both with 40 Gy in 20 fractions and simultaneous integrated boost with a dose of 14 Gy. Pathological complete response (pCR) will be considered as the study endpoint. Secondary endpoints include overall survival, quality of life, and acute and late toxicities.RESULTS: Between June 2007 and now, 39 patients have been enrolled in the study. Eleven patients were excluded: 4 due to unacceptable performance status, 1 for unacceptable concomitant diseases, 4 for major complications of surgery, and 2 for refusal to give consent. The remaining 28 patients were randomized. Ten patients were assigned to group 1, 10 to group 2, 6 to group 3, and 2 to group 4. Concomitant (and neoadjuvant) docetaxel was not given in any group. Patients included will be randomized into three equal groups: Group A. Patients in group A will receive TACE for three months. Group B. In group B, the treatment will be intensified from one cycle (90-minute iodized oil TACE cycle) every three months to two cycles (30-minute normal saline TACE cycle) every month for three months. At the same time, the patients will be treated with CRT after stent implantation (TACE and stent implantation will be done at the same puncture).  If the second cycle (50% of the TACE cycle) will be completed within 30 days, it will be stopped because 80% of the maximum dose has been reached. In addition, patients will receive oral sorafenib (400 mg bid for 17 days and oral sorafenib is discontinued for 5 weeks, three cycles) during three months.Group C. In group C, the treatment will be intensified from one cycle (90-minute iodized oil TACE cycle) every three months to two cycles (30-minute normal saline TACE cycle) every month for three months. At the same time, patients will receive oral sorafenib (400 mg bid for 17 days and oral sorafenib is discontinued for 5 weeks, three cycles), chemotherapy (capecitabine or fluorouracil) combined with CRT during three months after stent implantation and oral sorafenib (400 mg bid for 17 days and oral sorafenib is discontinued for 5 weeks, three cycles).

Abstract:
In patients with stable angina, ischemic symptoms and exercise‐induced dyspnea have been associated with impairments in functional capacity. We investigated whether the effect from ischemic symptoms and exercise‐induced dyspnea on functional capacity is similar after an invasive coronary angiogram.A post hoc analysis was performed from patients from the CABG or PCI for stable coronary artery disease. Subjects underwent a cardiopulmonary exercise test. Signs and symptoms of angina pectoris, dyspnea, and functional capacity were documented. Subjects with stable angina (symptoms of angina >3% of the week), exercise‐induced dyspnea, and no dyspnea (no anginal or dyspnea symptoms) were identified. Functional capacity was documented as peak oxygen consumption and the six‐minute walk test. After correction for age, sex, and body mass index, we found that subjects with stable angina had lower functional capacity. Exercise‐induced dyspnea was associated with a significant decrease in functional capacity. The association between angina and exercise‐induced dyspnea on functional capacity was not observed.Patients with both stable angina and exercise‐induced dyspnea more commonly underwent subsequent invasive coronary angiography.

Certainly! Here are the outcome measures we have discussed:

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Change in atrial fibrillation burden: The primary endpoint is the atrial fibrillation burden in the 6 months following renal denervation compared to the 3 months before renal denervation as assessed by the implantable cardiac monitor.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Freedom from atrial fibrillation recurrence: Assessing freedom from atrial fibrillation recurrence at 12 months after renal denervation.
2. Time to first atrial fibrillation recurrence after renal denervation: Evaluating the duration until the first recurrence of atrial fibrillation post-treatment.
3. Change in mean number of days with atrial fibrillation: Comparing the mean number of days with atrial fibrillation in the 6 months following renal denervation to the 3 months before, as assessed by the implantable cardiac monitor.
4. Evolution of AF burden measured as mean number of days with atrial fibrillation in the 12 months following renal denervation, as compared to before renal denervation.
5. Evolution of AF burden measured as mean number of days with atrial fibrillation in the 3 years following renal denervation, as compared to before renal denervation.
6. Change in arterial blood pressure after renal denervation: Comparing arterial blood pressure 3 months and 12 months after renal denervation to pre-treatment measurements using ambulatory and office blood pressure measurements.
7. Change in day heart rate following renal denervation: Evaluating day heart rate following renal denervation compared to before, as assessed by the implantable cardiac monitor.
8. Change in patient activity: Assessing patient activity following renal denervation compared to before, as assessed by the implantable cardiac monitor.
9. Change in heart rate variability: Monitoring heart rate variability following renal denervation compared to before, as assessed by the implantable cardiac monitor.
10. Change in night heart rate following renal denervation: Comparing night heart rate following renal denervation to before, as assessed by the implantable cardiac monitor.

The assessment includes evaluating the presence of erythema, wheal, bleeding, bruising, and induration following device removal. The assessment can be done using specific tissue effects scales. Wheal, erythema, and bleeding can be graded on a scale from 0 (absence of event) to 4 (most severe presence of event), while bruising and induration can be reported as present or not. The assessment should be conducted upon device removal, as well as at 30 minutes and 2 hours after device removal.

Brief summary
=================
Pulp therapy (PT) often provides acceptable temporary results for children until they grow older and their teeth can be restored with permanent restorations, however, the optimal material for PT has not been yet established. A new pulp therapy material, sodium hexameta-phosphate (Dyract Pulp Therapy, Dentsply Sirona), should be assessed in children, because it shows promising longterm results in animals and may provide permanent pulp therapy in deciduous teeth.The aim of this study is to compare the pulpal response of teeth restored with sodium hexameta-phosphate and the standard material mineral trioxide aggregate (MTA) in children.The null hypothesis to be verified is that the success rates of both materials are not different.

Abstract:
This study evaluates the results of modified root canal treatment using MTA with 2 different methods of obturation. Ninety teeth were randomly assigned to 3 groups: single cone technique (Control S) (n=33), cold lateral compaction (Control C) (n=33), and single cone technique combined with Calci‐X (Calci‐X) (test group) (n=24). The primary aim was to evaluate the success rate of modified obturation after 12 months. The secondary evaluations included radiographic and histological evaluation of the healing apical region. A significantly greater amount of MTA was used using the single cone technique (77% vs. 66%) and when combined with Calci‐X (71% vs. 63%), with no difference between the groups (p<0.05). In the Calci‐X group, the mean apical packing was 4.9 g compared to 5.3 g in the control group (p<0.05). At the end of the study, a periapical radiolucency was present in 27.5% of the teeth treated with Calci‐X and 45% of control group teeth (p>0.05). The control S group, 6/11 teeth (54.5%), and control C group, 2/4 (50%), showed periapical radiolucency or healing with signs of inflammation, while the group treated with Calci‐X demonstrated success. No apical pathosis was observed in the group treated with Calci‐X. It seems that MTA obturation when combined with Calci‐X increases success rates without the need for an additional filling material or compaction technique.

Abstract:
Background and Aims: To assess the effect of perinephric drainage (PND) on the rate of perforation in pediatric pyloric vein reconstruction (PVVR) and to determine whether the timing of PND affects its success. Methods: This is a retrospective study in children who underwent elective PVVR for congenital esophageal atresia and tracheoesophageal fistula. The following parameters were measured: 1. rate of perforation, 2. time to achieve PND, 3. effect of early and late PND on success. Results: From 2016 to 2021, 83 patients underwent laparotomy for PVVR and 7 (8.4%) patients had perforations. Of these 7 patients, 4 had early perforations that were treated successfully with delayed PND, and 3 had late complications that required operative intervention and PVVR ligation. Conclusions: Perinephrine drainage can be performed either early or late, and both are associated with similar success rates. As a result, we've decided to modify our operative approach. PVVR patients will continue to undergo early PND when no perforation is present but will undergo late PND if any perforation is discovered. This will allow us to avoid post‐operative complications of early PND, such as catheter occlusion and increased infectious complications, and maintain the same success rate. (Table Presented).

An exploratory study on the safety and efficacy of a novel drug, naloxone, as a potential treatment for the withdrawal syndrome associated with opioid abuse and dependence

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Naloxone (Nal) is a narcotic antagonist with a longer duration of action than competing opioid antagonists. Using oral dosing, several studies with Nal have shown it to be an effective blocker of heroin and other opioids. This exploratory trial attempts to expand upon this data by studying the use of Nal in opioid‐dependent individuals during an acute withdrawal episode.METHODS: We conducted a study in 12 opioid‐dependent volunteers (seven men and five women with a mean +/‐ SD age of 29.3 +/‐ 5.1) who had been abstinent only as part of study participation. All participants were healthy, except for a prior history of addiction. We performed a randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled, crossover trial in which volunteers were given either four placebo capsules or 100 mg Nal four times a day for five days. The primary endpoint was the percentage of time symptoms of acute withdrawal were present over a 40‐day post‐treatment period. Introduction
This study aims to assess the effectiveness of a parenting intervention on food motivation and healthy eating habits in highly food motivated children. Food motivation can be defined as the extent to which individuals perceive food as being rewarding and reinforcing. Parents have a crucial role in shaping their children's food motivation and eating habits, and interventions that target parenting practices have the potential to prevent childhood obesity. The study will target 375 caregiver-child dyads with one or more children aged 4-5 years who exhibit excessive food consumption and are considered highly food motivated.

Several studies have shown that inadequate parenting practices can contribute to the development of obesity in children. For example, a study by Tate and colleagues (2003) found that parents who have a laissez-faire parenting style are more likely to have children who are overweight or obese. Other studies have shown that restrictive feeding practices, such as pressuring children to eat or using food as a reward or bribe, can also increase the risk of obesity in children.

Some studies have shown that parenting approaches can be effective in preventing childhood obesity. For example, a study by Barr and colleagues (2009) found that a parenting intervention that focused on decreasing restrictive feeding practices and promoting autonomy-supportive feeding practices was effective in reducing excessive food consumption in children with obesity. Another study by Birch and colleagues (2001) found that a parenting intervention that focused on promoting healthy eating habits and decreasing unhealthy food choices was effective in preventing obesity in children.

To our knowledge, there are no studies that have focused specifically on highly food motivated children and their parents. This project aims to address this gap by developing and testing a parenting intervention designed to promote healthy eating habits and prevent obesity in children who are highly food motivated.

Study design

Prospective open-label clinical observatory and laboratory study

Description
=================
The first part of the observatory study is a preliminary study with 10 participants. The preliminary study is intended to be completed within one period. In the observatory study, the effects of a 5% carbohydrate diet with a defined carbohydrate loading day are compared with the effects of a low-carbohydrate diet with a carbohydrate loading day in 10 physically fit participants. In the observatory laboratory study, the metabolic effects of a defined carbohydrate loading day and the impact of a 5%-6% carbohydrate diet on 20 healthy subjects of both sexes will be examined. In the observatory study, the study population will be evaluated for gastrointestinal tolerance, blood sugar and lactate (GLL), and blood metabolites (glycerol, glucose, insulin, non-esterified fatty acids, ketone bodies, free fatty acids) at rest and during exercise before and after each intervention period.
Body weight and resting energy expenditure (REE) will be measured at rest before each intervention period and the day before the end of the observation period. Blood lactate (GLL) concentration is determined before and during an incremental cycle ergometer test as part of routine care.
It is estimated that the laboratory and observatory studies will each require 12-15 days of participant stay. During this period, the subjects will follow the diet that is determined by randomization. After 5 intervention days and with at least 1 day of washout, the participants will change to the other diet and follow it for another 5 days. On completion of the intervention period, 2 non-consecutive days of rest should be observed. The two study periods should be started 1 week apart. On completion of the 2-week intervention period, a day of rest should be observed. The laboratory stay is completed with a 6-hour blood sugar laboratory analysis. The results of the blood chemistry and the body composition will be taken into account and the results will be analyzed.

Intervention Description:: We will use a behavioral intervention to target cognitive reappraisal skills in adolescents who are at risk for obesity and who have a high BMI. Cognitive reappraisal is a coping strategy that involves changing the way individuals think about a stressful or negative event, which can help reduce their negative emotions and improve their well-being. In this study, we will teach adolescents to use cognitive reappraisal skills in response to stressful daily events such as teasing or peer pressure. The intervention will be delivered through an evidence-based curriculum that takes approximately 20 weeks to complete. The curriculum will include activities and exercises that will help adolescents practice and master cognitive reappraisal skills. For example, adolescents will be asked to identify a stressful or negative event, take a few minutes to think about it in different ways, and rate their emotions before and after the exercise. The focus of this study is to determine whether teaching cognitive reappraisal skills to adolescents who are at risk for obesity can help reduce their weight gain and prevent obesity.

Abstract:
Introduction: Perineal trauma is a common occurrence during childbirth, and can cause pain, bleeding, and discomfort for the mother. It can also lead to long‐term complications such as urinary incontinence and sexual dysfunction. The use of perineal warm compression techniques during the second stage of labor has been suggested as a potential method to reduce the incidence of perineal trauma. Objectives: This study aims to evaluate the effects of perineal warm compression techniques during the second stage of labor on perineal pain and trauma among primiparous women. Materials and Methods: A randomized controlled trial was conducted at a tertiary care center in Pakistan. Primiparous women with a cephalic fetus in the vertex presentation were included in the study. The intervention group received perineal warm compression during the second stage of labor, while the control group received standard care without the use of warm compresses.The primary outcome measure was the incidence of perineal tears. Primary outcome measure was the incidence of perineal tears. Secondary outcome measure were: 1: Incidence and the level of pain intensity. 2: Length of second stage. 3: Apgar scores. 4: Fetal well‐being. Results: A total of 320 primiparous women participated in the study. The incidence of perineal tears was significantly lower in the intervention group (6.25%) compared to the control group (31.25%) (p= 0.018). The intervention group also reported significantly lower levels of pain intensity compared to the control group (p= 0.01). The length of the second stage was similar in both groups. The incidence of fetal distress was low in both groups, and there was no significant difference in Apg

It allows for better targeting of the treatment, which can increase the rate of complete resection and decrease the risk of recurrence. The technique also reduces the need for repeat surgeries and improves patient outcomes. This may increase the risk of radiation-induced harm, such as cancer or other adverse events. The procedure may also be technically more challenging, requiring specialized expertise and equipment. In addition, the technique may be more expensive, which can contribute to healthcare costs.
